mtliZOAd.title: Synthesis of thermally stable and highly ordered bicontinuous cubic mesoporous titania–silica binary oxides with crystalline framework
mtliZOAd.abstract: Highly ordered bicontinuous cubic mesoporous titania–silica binary oxides were synthesized via evaporation-induced self-assembly (EISA) method. X-ray diffraction (XRD), fourier transform infrared spectra (FT-IR), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), BET surface area and BJH pore-size distribution have been used to determine the mesostructrues and properties of the samples. The resultant materials are thermally stable (up to 600 °C), and show high surface areas (110–234 m 2 /g), uniform pore diameters (∼3.3 nm). And the pore wall framework is composed of anatase and minor rutile phases. The effects of acidity, water content in sol and heat treatment temperature on the formation and thermal stability of mesoporous structures were investigated. Photodegradation of Rhodamine B (RhB) under UV light irradiation shows that the sample has a comparable photocatalytic activity with Degussa P25, and higher activity than pure TiO 2 . Keywords Mesoporous Titania Silica Thermal stability Photocatalyst 1 Introduction Since the MCM type mesostructured silica was first fabricated in the early 1990s [1] , series of non-siliceous mesoporous materials have been synthesized. Among them, mesoporous titania as one of the most promising photocatalysts has attracted intense interest for its advantages such as high efficiency, availability and nontoxicity [2–4] . In 1995, Antonelli and Ying [5] synthesized mesoporous titania for the first time. From then on, many attempts have been made to synthesize nanocrytalline mesoporous titania [6–8] . However, it is still much more difficult to prepare highly ordered nanocrystalline mesoporous titania with highly thermal stability. Evaporation-induced self-assembly (EISA) method [9] is an efficient method for preparing highly ordered mesoporous titania, which was first extended to prepare non-siliceous mesoporous materials by Yang et al. [10,11] . However, the crystallinity of the mesoporous titania framework was usually not satisfied, and high temperature treatment often lead to the collapse of ordered mesostructure. An enormous difficulty in successfully synthesizing ordered crystalline titania mesostructures is the thermal stability of the inorganic network upon removal of the template [12] . Titania mesostructures have such poor thermal stability that the calcination of mesoporous titania often results in either poorly ordered materials or fully collapsed structures. The collapse is believed to be caused by the intrinsical crystallization of amorphous TiO 2 into anatase phase and crystal growth during calcinations [13,14] . In most cases, the mesostructures collapse and the porosity is destroyed mostly after being calcined above 400 °C. Many efforts have been made to improve their thermal stabilities [15–18] . A widespread route to resolve the stability problem of mesoporous titania is to incorporate another inorganic oxide such as SiO 2 , Al 2 O 3 , P 2 O 5 , ZrO 2 , WO 3 [19] into the mesostructured TiO 2 frameworks. Yang and co-workers [10,11] synthesized many ordered mesoporous metal oxides such as TiO 2 , ZrO 2 , Al 2 O 3 , SiO 2 using block copolymer surfactants. Although they also claimed that they synthesized two-dimensional hexagonal SiTiO y , Al 2 TiO y , ZrTiO y composites, the inorganic wall structure of the samples were amorphous, and detailed reports on the synthesis have not been given yet. Kim et al. [20] studied the effect on the stability of bimodal porous TiO 2 doped with Al 2 O 3 , ZrO 2 , SiO 2 . They concluded that the dopants not only delayed the anatase–rutile phase transition, but also retarded the crystallite growth of anatase titania. There are many reports about mesoprous titania–silica materials [21–23] , however, few reports referred to ordered mesoporous titania–silica binary oxides because of the different hydrolysis–condensation rate between titania source and silica source. Li et al. [24] synthesized hexagonal mesoporous SiO 2 /TiO 2 composite materials, and investigated the influences of aging conditions on the samples. They claimed that the materials have crystallized framework, but the crystallinity is not well. Additionally, thermal stability and photocatalytic activities of the samples have not been investigated. Li and co-workers [13] claimed that they fabricated a kind of ordered mesoporous anatase-based TiO 2 –SiO 2 nanocomposites and the ordered mesostructure remains up to 700 °C, however, detailed works on the synthesis and properties have not been given. Zhao and co-workers [25] studied the synthesis, structure and themal stability of ordered hexagonal mesostructured TiO 2 –SiO 2 nanocomposites. They found that the amorphous silica acts as a glue linking the TiO 2 nanocrystals in the mesostructured frameworks and improves the thermal stability greatly. However, the synthetic period was time-consuming (about 10 days) and the required crystallization conditions were severe (350 °C for 6 h). To date, ordered cubic mesoporous titania–silica bianry oxides have not been reported. The mesoporous architecture may have a significant impact on the photocatalytic activity of titania–silica binary oxides. The interconncted mesochannels in the cubic mesoprous titania–silica binary oxides can serve as efficient transport paths for reactants and products and make a contribution to the photocatalytic activity [26] . In the present work, we report for the first time to synthesize highly ordered bicontinuous cubic mesoporous titania–silica binary oxides with uniform pore sizes, high surface areas and excellent thermal stability. Such a mesoporous sructural feature may have interesting bulk-chemistry applications, especially for heterogeneous photocatalysis due to its high suface area and continuous pore channels [27] . The effects of acidity, water content in sol and heat treatment temperature on the formation and thermal stability of mesoporous structures were investigated. The adsorption study and photocatalytic test of the samples were also investigated with comparison to that of Degussa P25. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Pluronic F127 [F127, HO(CH 2 CH 2 O) 106 [CH 2 CH(CH 3 )O] 70 (CH 2 CH 2 O) 106 H] was purchased from Sigma–Aldrich. Titanium isopropoxide [TTIP, Ti(OCH(CH 3 ) 2 ) 4 ] was received from J&K Corp. Tetraethyl orthosilicate [TEOS, Si(OC 2 H 5 ) 4 ], concentrated HCl (37 wt.%) and absolute ethanol (EtOH, CH 2 CH 3 OH) were all analytical grade. All chemicals were used as received. 2.2 Synthesis methods The highly ordered bicontinuous cubic mesoporous titania–silica binary oxides were prepared by EISA method, using TTIP and TEOS as precursors and F127 as template. The molar ratio of the ingredients was (TTIP + TEOS):HCl:H 2 O:F127:EtOH = 1:(1.00–2.00):(7–15):0.005:30, TTIP:TEOS = 4:1. In a typical synthesis, 0.4 mL TEOS was mixed with 2.15 mL TTIP under stirring for 15 min, then a solution containing 1.1 mL concentrated HCl, 1 mL anhydrous EtOH and 0.8 mL distilled H 2 O was slowly added with vigorous stirring. During that time, the peptization of the initial precipitate occurred, generating a clear yellow sol. To generate nanocrystalline anatase and make TEOS hydrolyze, the sol was aged for 2 h at 35 °C before a structuring agent was added under stirring. Then a template solution prepared by dissolving 0.604 g F127 in 15 mL anhydrous EtOH was added dropwise to the sol. The resulting clear colorless sol was stirred vigorously for 3 h at room temperature. Then the mother sol solution was transferred from the reactor onto a flat glass with an area of 600 cm 2 . The sol extended sufficiently and formed an uniform thin layer. In the aging stage, the environmental humidity and the aging temperature were kept at 55–60% and 35 °C, respectively for about 3 days, then the cracked-free transparent thin layer was dried at 80 °C for 12 h, 100 °C for 12 h, 130 °C for 12 h in air to stabilize the mesostructure. Finally, the sample was heat-treated at 400–700 °C for 2 h in air with the heating rate of 1 °C/min and cooling rate of 5 °C/min. The samples were labeled as TS- x - y - t , where x and y corresponded to the initial mole ratios of HCl/(Ti + Si) and H 2 O/(Ti + Si), respectively, and t was the corresponding calcination temperatures (°C). Especially, the samples prepared with the HCl/(Ti + Si) = 1.5 and H 2 O/(Ti + Si) = 10 and calcined at different temperatures were denoted as TS- t . For comparison, pure TiO 2 was synthesized in the same procedure but without adding TEOS. And the molar ratio of the ingredients was TTIP:HCl:H 2 O:F127:EtOH = 1:1.50:10:0.005:30. The obtained sample calcined at 400 °C for 2 h was signed as P–TiO 2 . 2.3 Characterization Low-angle X-ray diffraction (SAXRD) patterns of all samples were collected in θ –2 θ mode using Rigaku D/MAX-2550 diffractometer (Cu Kα 1 radiation, λ = 1.5406 Å), operated at 40 kV and 200 MA. Wide-angle X-ray diffraction (WAXRD) patterns were collected in the same mode, but operated at 100 MA. The crystallite size was estimated by applying the Scherrer equation to the FWHM of the (1 0 1) peak of anatase, with α-silicon (99.9999%) as a standard for the instrumental line broading. The FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Magna 380 spectrometer. The sample was observed by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) in a 2100 JEOL apparatus at 200 kV. The porous structures of the samples have been measured using the BET method by nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms at −196 °C. Before measurement, samples were evacuated overnight at 200 °C. By using a Micromeritics ASAP 2000 system, the BET and BJH methods were applied for the determination of the specific surface area, and the mean mesoporous equivalent diameter, respectively. The methylene blue (MB) adsorption study was carried out as follows: 50 mg of catalyst was suspended in 50 mL of MB aqueous solution (20 mg/L). The suspension was then agitated in the dark for 60 min to achieve the adsorption–desorption equilibrium on the catalyst surface. The residual MB in the solution was analyzed by checking the absorbance at 660 nm with a UV–vis spectrophotometer (Varian Cary 100). The adsorption of MB is calculated by the initial concentration minus the residual concentration. The photocatalytic activity of each sample was evaluated from an analysis of photocatalytic degradation of RhB solution. 50 mg of catalyst was suspended in 50 mL of RhB aqueous solution (20 mg/L) using a 100 mL capacity glass tube. The suspension was then agitated in the dark for 60 min to achieve the adsorption–desorption equilibrium on the catalyst surface. Then the solution was irradiated with a high-pressure Hg lamp (300 W, 254–600 nm, λ max = 365 nm). The distance between the light source and the reaction tube was 20 cm. At regular irradiation intervals, the residual RhB in the solution was centrifuged and analyzed by checking the absorbance at 553 nm with an UV–vis spectrophotometer (Varian Cary 100). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 X-ray diffraction The effects of acidity, water content in sol and heat treatment temperature on the formation and thermal stability of mesoporous structures were investigated through Small-angle X-ray powder diffraction (SAXRD) and Wide-angle X-ray powder diffraction (SAXRD). 3.1.1 Effects of acid Fig. 1 shows the SAXRD patterns of samples prepared with various HCl/(Ti + Si) molar ratios. From the variation of diffraction peaks, it can be found that the acidity of solution has a crucial effect on the order of mesostructures. When the H 2 O/(Ti + Si) molar ratio is fixed at 10, the appropriate HCl/(Ti + Si) molar ratio is in the range of 1.00–1.75, and the optimal HCl/(Ti + Si) ratio is 1.50. If HCl/(Ti + Si) < 1.00, no clear sol can be attained. Practically, no ordered mesostructure can be obtained when the HCl/(Ti + Si) ratio in solution is lower than 1.00 or higher than 1.75. In the acidic medium (i.e. lower HCl/(Ti + Si)), protons are adsorbed on the surface of titania oligomers (NBB) and silicate oligomers, which derive from the hydrolyzation of TTIP and TEOS respectively. Under the low acid concentration condition, the positive charge of protons which oligomers adsorb is too weak to control condensation. The indiscriminate condensation hinders the disorder-to-order transition before the formation of organized mesophases. On the contrary, under the high acid concentration condition (i.e. higher HCl/(Ti + Si)), more protons are adsorbed on the surface of titania oligomers and silica oligomers. The repulsive force becomes stronger and the inorganic polymerization is restrained [28] , which makes the condensation more difficult. Thus, it is hard to obtain organized mesostructure in this condition. 3.1.2 Effects of water content in sol SAXRD patterns of the samples prepared with various water contents in sol are illustrated in Fig. 2 . The results suggest that the water content in sol also influence the order of mesostructures. The suitable range of H 2 O/(Ti + Si) molar ratio is 7–15 when the HCl/(Ti + Si) molar ratio is fixed at 1.50. If the H 2 O/(Ti + Si) molar ratio is lower than 7, organized mesostructure can not be obtained. The inadequate folding of the F127 template is responsible for the lack of long-rang order. On the other hand, it is impossible to obtain clear sol with the H 2 O/(Ti + Si) molar ratio higher than 15 and hardly get organized mesostructure. The enrichment of the system in water is beneficial for adequately hydrolyzing the inorganic species and condensation, but it also can be a detrimental effect on the organization. 3.1.3 Effects of heat treatment Fig. 3 shows the SAXRD patterns of the mesostructured titania–silica binary oxides heat-treated at different temperatures. The as-synthesized, TS-400 and TS-500 samples all exhibit two well-resolved diffraction peaks which assigned to a cubic symmetry. The two peaks can be indexed as (1 1 0) and (1 1 1) reflections, for the d value ratio of the two peaks is determined to √2/√3, suggesting that the space group of the mesostructure is bicontinuous cubic Pn 3 ¯ m [29] . After calcination at 500 °C, two well-resolved diffraction peaks can still be observed ( Fig. 3 b and c), indicating that the samples have high thermal stability. The sample TS-600 shows only one (1 1 0) diffraction peak, the (1 1 1) peak disappears. This suggests that the well-ordered mesostructure is partly destroyed. The destruction of mesostruture is caused by the further growth of nanocrystalline TiO 2 [30,31] . However, the main domain of the ordered mesostructure is still maintained. There is only an ambiguous peak appeared at the pattern of the sample TS-700, suggesting a complete collapse of the mesostructure. The d (1 1 0) spacings of the samples as-synthesized, TS-400, TS-500 and TS-600 are 9.21, 8.86, 8.44, 8.02 nm, respectively. The shrinkage of the cell parameters for the bicontinuous cubic mesostructure still proceeds continuously up to 600 °C. It is noted that the P–TiO 2 without adding TEOS exhibits no diffraction peak ( Fig. 3 f), indicating that silica as a mesostructure stabilizer plays a key role in the enhancement of thermal stability. The WAXRD patterns ( Fig. 4 ) of mesostructured titania–silica binary oxides show the effects of calcination temperature on phase structures of the sample. The as-synthesized sample shows several broad diffraction peaks, suggesting the formation of TiO 2 nanocrystallites [32] . The characteristic peaks of anatase and rutile are labeled in Fig. 4 , respectively. Comparison to the mesoporous titania–silica composites reported previously [24,25] , whose wall structures were composed of pure anatase, mixed-phase crystal textures can be observed in our samples. The samples present a main phase of anatase with small amount of rutile. It has been widely reported that a certain amount of HCl can favor the growth of rutile nuclei [33–34] . In hydrochloric acid solution, the hydroxide groups in the pair of octahedrons sharing one edge are protonated. When a neighboring octahedron attacks the pair of octahedrons, the electrostatic repulsion between the neighboring octahedrons is favorable to further share the opposite edge between neighboring octahedrons. As a result, linear chairs of octahedrons are formed by continuously sharing the opposite edges, which lead to the formation of rutile. During calcination treatment, the intensities of diffraction peaks increase, indicating higher crystallization of titania particles. The sample calcined at 400, 500, 600, 700 °C shows a strongest peak at 2 θ = 25.72°, 25.38°, 25.38°, 25.32°, respectively, representative of (1 0 1) anatase phase reflections. Compared with pure anatase whose strongest peak generally shows at 2 θ = 25.28°, the peak positions shift slightly toward higher angles. Similarly, the peak positions of rutile also shift, implying a distortion of the crystal lattice of TiO 2 . The distortion is probably caused by the silica incorporating into the framework of mesoporous TiO 2 , a little part of Ti 4+ ions (ionic radius is 0.074 nm) are substituted by Si 4+ ions (ionic radius is 0.041 nm) and that leads to form Ti–O–Si in the lattice of TiO 2 . The 2 θ value of the sample decreases from 25.72° to 25.32° when the calcination temperature increases from 400 to 700 °C. It indicates that the Ti–O–Si bonds in the network of TiO 2 are partly disassociated. As the calcination temperature increases, the diffraction peaks of anatase phase become strong and narrow, denoting a higher degree of crystallinity and larger crystal sizes. However, the diffraction peaks of rutile phase have little change even at 700 °C. It implies that the crystallinity and size of rutile almost unchange during heat treatment. There are two possible reasons responsible for this. One probable reason is that the content of rutile is very low and the rutile particles can not grow upon these temperatures [35] . The other is that both the Ti–O–Si interface and the silica glass phase hindered the growth of rutile and restrained the transition of anatase-to-rutile. The sizes of anatase nanocrystals calcined at different temperature are calculated based on the Scherrer–Debye formula and listed in Table 1 . The anatase size of the sample calcined at 700 °C (8.1 nm) is smaller than that of P–TiO 2 (8.3 nm), indicating that the addition of silica could efficiently inhibit the crystal growth of TiO 2 particles during the calcinations process, which is in favor of improving the thermal stability. 3.2 Infrared spectra Silica is believed to play an important role in enhancing the thermal stability of the samples probably due to the generation of Ti–O–Si bond. The presence of the Ti–O–Si vibration band in the mesostructure titania–silica binary oxides was confirmed by the FT-IR spectra ( Fig. 5 a). The spectrum of the sample TS-600 shows a peak at 949 cm −1 belonged to asymmetric stretching vibration of the Ti–O–Si bond [36–38] . This bond is possibly ascribed to the SiO 4 tetrahedron bonded to a titanium atom. The silica is incorporated into the framework of mesoporous TiO 2 and a little part of Ti 4+ ions are substituted by Si 4+ ions. This is in agreement with the WAXRD result. The band at 1180 cm −1 is due to the asymmetrical vibration of the Si–O–Si bond in the bulk silica [36–38] . It is noted that the peak of Ti–O–Si is not strong enough, which indicates that the quantity of silicon incorporated into the TiO 2 lattice is limited and the main silicon exists as amorphous silica. The amorphous silica can prevent the titania particles aggregating together and further growing into large scale, which makes the mesostructures avoid collapsing. The low-frequency band at 453 cm −1 is attributed to the Ti–O–Ti vibration of the sample [39,40] . The peak at 1628 cm −1 corresponds to the bending vibrations of O–H, and the broad bands around 3416 cm −1 are assigned to the surface adsorbed water and hydroxyl groups [41] . The intensity of these two peaks are stronger than that of the pure TiO 2 calcined at 600 °C, suggesting more hydroxyl groups on the surface of the sample TS-600 due to the addition of silica, which can act as Lewis acid sites to easily adsorb oxygen and water molecules, possibly corresponding to a more powerful redox ability for photocatalytic reaction. 3.3 Transmission electron microscopy The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images ( Fig. 6 ) of the samples confirmed that the mesostructured titania–silica binary oxides have a well-ordered bicontinuous cubic mesostructure. The materials show a laylike feature ( Fig. 6 a) at 400 °C, and a gridlike feature ( Fig. 6 c and d) at 500 and 600 °C, for pores have merged in preferential directions. It is consistent with previous reports [17,42] . At high calcination temperature, highly ordered mesoporous patterns are presented in large domain. The sample exhibits mesoporous channels from 3 to 4 nm and pore wall thicknesses from 4 to 5 nm, which is in agreement with the SAXRD patterns. The HRTEM image ( Fig. 6 b) shows both nanocrystals and amorphous phase of the framework. And the nanocrystals are found to be embedded in the amorphous phase with random orientation. Crystal planes can be clearly seen in the HRTEM image and the average d-spacing of the lattice fringes of the sample TS-400 measured from it is about 0.36 nm, which is in good agreement with the anatase d-spacing value (0.35 nm) calculated from the WAXRD data. Fourier-transform of the selected area ( Fig. 6 b inset) show some ambiguous diffraction rings of nanocrystals, which indicates the crystallinity is not very well, corresponding well with the WAXRD patterns. As the calcination temperature increases, the pore architecture is destroyed gradually. The self-assembly and structure evolution process is illustrated in Scheme 1 . In the peptization stage, TTIP and TEOS hydrolyze synchronously in the existence of HCl. Large amount of HCl can slow down the condensation and polymerization of TTIP and accelerate the hydrolysis of TEOS simultaneously. In the aging stage, titania species and silica species co-assembly with F127 and form ordered mesostructures. During the calcination process, titanate oligomers and silicate oligomers can cross-link with each other through Ti–O–Si bonds. Silica act as a glue between TiO 2 nanocrystals and improve the thermal stability of the meosostructures. However, when the calcination temperature increase up to 700 °C, silica can not effectively inhibit the growth of TiO 2 nanocrystals and the mesostructrures are destroyed. 3.4 Nitrogen adsorption–desorption Fig. 7 shows the representative N 2 adsorption– desorption isotherms and Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) pore-size distribution plots of the samples. All isotherms of the samples show similar type IV isotherms, which are representative of mesoporous materials according to the IUPAC classification. The isotherms display a H 2 hysteresis loop with a triangular shape and a steep desorption branch. The H 2 type loop indicates that the samples have ink-bottle-shaped or cage-type pores [43,44] , which is correspondence with the TEM images ( Fig. 6 ). BJH pore-size analyses using BJH model show that the mesostructured titania–silica binary oxdies have a mean pore size in the range of 3.2–3.5 nm, implying the samples possess very regular pore channels. The half-height width of the pore-size distribution shows a narrow pore-size distribution, which is of great importance in selective adsorption of organic molecules. The textural properties of the samples calcined at different temperatures are listed in Table 1 .The sample TS-400 shows high BET surface area (234 m 2 g −1 ) and pore volume (0.18 cm −3 g −1 ). The BET surface area and pore volume of the sample decreases to 110 m 2 g −1 and 0.09 cm −3 g −1 , respectively when the temperature increases to 700 °C. As the temperature increases, the BET surface area and pore volume of samples decrease gradually. This suggests a partly destroy of the mesostructure due to the growth of the crystallites, which agrees with the SAXRD ( Fig. 3 ) results. However, the pore size is not significantly changed with the calcinations temperature increasing, which can be ascribed to the high thermal stability of mesoporous framework. 3.5 MB adsorption study As we know, the continuous pore channels can facilitate the transfer of reactant molecules, and the periodic surface structure allows structural orientation of guest molecules in the pores, which may result in the enhancement of activity and selectivity in catalysis [45] . However, if the pore channels are blocked, the reactants can not get into the pore channels and proceed reaction. Thus, the accessible pore of mesostructure materials makes an important effect on the efficiency of reaction occurring within the architecture. And accessible interconnected mesoporous structure is a particularly important property for maintaining a fast mass-transfer throughout the pore architecture. We investigated the accessible pore of the samples using MB as a probe molecule. MB is a kind of cationic dye with molecule diameter 1.1–1.2 nm, and the adsorption of MB by metal oxides such as TiO 2 follows the Langmuir adsorption isotherm [46] . The well-defined optical absorption of MB provide an easy way to measure the accessible pore of the samples. Fig. 8 shows the adsorption of MB for the samples TS-400, TS-500, TS-600 and TS-700 compared with P–TiO 2 and Degussa P25. The adsorptions of the mesostructured titania–silica binary oxides were 4–5 times than that of P–TiO 2 and Degussa P25. The results indicate that the titania–silica binary oxides have open-pore structures and the probe molecule can get into the pore channel easily, which is favorable for photodegradation reaction. 3.6 Photocatalytic performance The photacatalytic degradation of RhB solution under UV light irradiation has been selected as a model reaction to evaluate the photoactivity of the synthesized mesostructured titania–silica binary oxides. The degradation yield of RhB removal at various time intervals and the plot of −ln( C / C 0 ) versus time are illustrated in Fig. 9 . The photocatalytic activity of commercial photocatalyst Degussa P25 was measured under identical conditions for comparison. The reaction follows first-order kinetics and the initial reaction rate constants were calculated according to the formula −ln( C / C 0 ) = kt , where C / C 0 is the normalized organic compounds concentration and k is the apparent reaction rate constant. At 400 °C, the mesostructured titania–silica binary oxide exhibits inferior photocatalytic activity ( k c = 0.0101 min −1 ), even though it has large surface area, which is due to its low crystallinity degree. With the calcination temperature increasing, the photocatalytic activity increases, which is ascribed to higher crystallinity degree. The mesostructured titania–silica binary oxides calcined at 500 °C ( k d = 0.0180 min −1 ) shows similar photocatalytic activities with that of P–TiO 2 ( k b = 0.0187 min −1 ). And the mesostructured titania–silica binary oxides calcined at 600 and 700 °C show much better activities than that of P–TiO 2 , which maybe attributed to their high surface areas, open-pore structures and high surface acidity due to the addition of silica. The sample calcined at 600 °C ( k e = 0.0456 min −1 ) shows the best catalytic effect, which is as high as that of Degussa P25 ( k a = 0.0458 min −1 ), and the percentage of degraded RhB reached 95% after 60 min. It is noted that the Ti content of TS-600 is much lower than that of P25. Thus the titania photocatalytic efficiency of TS-600 is considered to be better than that of P25. The sample TS-700 shows lower photocatalytic activity than that of TS-600, probably due to the sharply decrease of the surface area, loss of order mesosturcture and increase of crystallite size after calcination. 4 Conclusions Highly ordered bicontinuous cubic titania–silica binary oxides have been prepared effectively through EISA method. The solution acidity and sol water content show important effects on the formation of ordered mesostructures. To obtain ordered mesostructures, suitable HCl/(Ti + Si) and H 2 O/(Ti + Si) molar ratios are necessary. The synthesized samples exhibit high thermal stability (up to 600 °C) due to the existence of silica. The silica is well-dispersed into the titania framework without phase seperation. And the titania and silica link with each other through Ti–O–Si bonds. Therefore, the silica can suppress the crystallite growth and inhibit the anatase–rutile phase transformation, which are benefit for the stability of mesostructures. The mesostructured titania–silica binary oxides have high surface areas, uniform pore diameters, open-pore structures and small nanocrystal sizes, which is favorable for the photodegradation of RhB under the irradiation of UV light. Sc8aSohc.title: Synthesis of bi-porous TiO2 with crystalline framework using a double surfactant system
Sc8aSohc.abstract: A mesoporous TiO 2 with crystalline framework was synthesized by nanocrystalline particle assembly using a double surfactant system. Hydrothermal treatment was adopted in order to improve the crystallinity of mesoporous framework. The XRD patterns, HRTEM and TEM images indicate that the as-synthesized product is mesoporous structure and the pore wall is crystalline structure. Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherm reveals that there is the bi-porous structure in the sample calcined at 523 K. A controlled calcination process using a slow and constant heating rate was adopted so that the mesoporous structure of the sample could be retained to 673 K. Keywords Mesopores Micropores TiO 2 Hydrothermal treatment Double surfactant system

yIdY59VM.title: Study of adsorption and degradation of acid orange 7 on the surface of CeO2 under visible light irradiation
yIdY59VM.abstract: Cerium dioxide was prepared by the precipitation method and found to be an efficient photocatalyst to degrade azodyes under visible light irradiation. Nonbiodegradable azodyes acid orange 7 (AO7) was selected as modal target to examine the photocatalytic activity of CeO 2 . AO7 could be efficiently degraded in aqueous suspension of CeO 2 under visible light illumination. The catalyst was characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), N 2 sorption, transmission electron microscopic image (TEM) and UV/vis absorption spectrum techniques. AO7 solution was quickly decolorized and partly mineralized under visible light irradiation with existing CeO 2 . The photodegradation rate of this azodye catalyzed by CeO 2 is much faster than those occurring on commercial titania (Degussa P25) under otherwise identical conditions of visible light irradiation. Experiments were conducted to examine the adsorption mode of acid orange 7 on CeO 2 and adsorption capacity at different pH values. The possible degradation pathway has been proposed for the photocatalytic degradations by using certain radical scavengers and gas chromatography–mass spectrometry (GC–MS) to determine intermediates. The enhanced photoactivity of the lanthanide oxide CeO 2 was attributed to the superior adsorption capacity and special 4f electron configuration.

imYP2gAt.title: Synthesis of La3+ doped mesoporous titania with highly crystallized walls
imYP2gAt.abstract: A simple synthetic method to prepare thermally stable La 3+ doped mesoporous titania with highly crystallized walls and high photocatalytic activity is reported. The crystalline framework derives from the assembly of nano-anatase particles. La 3+ doping is a critical factor to increase the stability and photocatalytic activity of mesoporous titania. The mesoporous materials were characterized by low angle and wide angle X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), N 2 adsorption–desorption and UV–visible absorbance spectroscopy. Characteristic results clearly show that La 3+ doped samples have highly regular mesoporous structures, and their crystallized walls are composed of nano-anatase particles. The photocatalytic activity of the prepared mesoporous titania powders was evaluated from an analysis of the photo-degradation of methyl orange. The results indicate that sample doped with 0.25 at% La 3+ , has the highest photocatalytic activity.

sjmPs1py.title: One-step preparation, characterization and visible-light photocatalytic activity of Cr-doped TiO 2 with anatase and rutile bicrystalline phases
sjmPs1py.abstract: Cr-doped TiO 2 (Cr-TiO 2) nanoparticles with anatase and rutile bicrystalline phases were synthesized by a simple one-step flame spray pyrolysis (FSP) technique. The influences of chromium doping on the phase composition, microstructures, and optical properties of Cr-TiO 2 were analyzed by the methods of XRD, TEM, EPR, XPS, UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy, and nitrogen adsorption-desorption. It was revealed that Cr 3+ doping not only extends the visible light response of TiO 2 but also increases the content of rutile in the bicrystalline TiO 2. XPS results confirmed that Cr 3+ can effectively promote the formation of oxygen vacancy which is contributed to the anatase-to-rutile transformation. EPR analysis indicated that the existing state of Cr in Cr-TiO 2 is closely relative to the Cr content: Cr is mainly incorporated into the crystal lattice of TiO 2 when the Cr content is lower than 1at.%, while higher Cr content is favorable to the formation of Cr 2O 3 clusters. The photocatalytic activities of different Cr-TiO 2 photocatalytsts were evaluated in terms of the photocatalytic degradation of 2,4-dichlorophenol (2,4-DCP) under visible light irradiation. Appropriate Cr 3+ doping can significantly enhance the visible-light photocatalytic activity of TiO 2, which is attributed to the improvement of visible light response as well as the suitable anatase-to-rutile ratio. Excess Cr 3+ doping is detrimental to the improvement of visible light photocatalytic activity, which is relative to the formation of Cr 2O 3 clusters as well as too high rutile content. © 2012 Elsevier B.V.

T0A0hBre.title: Direct synthesis of Cr-MCM-48-like large pore mesoporous silica
T0A0hBre.abstract:
Chromium-substituted MCM-48-like large pore mesoporous silica with average pore size up to 10 nm was directly synthesized
 by using P123 (EO20PO70EO20) as a template, n-butanol as an assistant, and chromic nitrate nonahydrate as a chromium source. The Cr species was doped by simply adjusting
 the pH of the synthesis system with ammonia from strong acid to nearly neutral after crystallization for 24 h. The Si/Cr ratios
 in the initial gel ranged from 10 to 80, and the actual weight percentage of Cr was analyzed by ICP. XRD pattern, high-resolution
 TEM, and N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm were employed to investigate the pore structure properties of these materials. The results
 showed that all the samples had Ia3d cubic structure and the pore channels were highly ordered. UV–vis, wide-angle XRD, and ESR spectra revealed that at lower
 Cr content (Si/Cr > 30), only Cr (VI) and Cr(V) species existed in the mesoporous framework, and at higher Cr content, Cr
 (III) species appeared.

6vCK5eFm.title: Study on the fluorescence properties of fluorescein dye incorporated into SBA-15
6vCK5eFm.abstract: Fluorescein was first introduced to the large pore channel of SBA-15 by impregnation method. UV–Vis absorption, fluorescence emission and lifetime were used to characterize the host–guest composite. The existing forms of fluorescein in SBA-15 consist of monoanion and dianion. The emission spectrum of fluorescein in SBA-15 shifts to blue about 10 nm and the fluorescence lifetime is largely prolonged compared with that in ethanol. The prolonged lifetime in SBA-15 is attributed to the high dispersion of fluorescein molecules in SBA-15 and the formation of hydrogen bond with silanols on the surface of SBA-15.

rqZ2u6Ud.title: Low-Temperature Preparation and Photocatalytic Performance of F-Doped Nanosized TiO_2 Thin Film
rqZ2u6Ud.abstract: F-doped TiO2(FTO) sol was prepared using NH4F as the fluorine precursor by a hydrothermal method.FTO thin film was then prepared via dip-coating.The TiO2 thin film prepared from the TiO2 sol that was hydrothermally treated at 120 oC for 10 h had preferable transparence and high photocatalytic activity.F doping did not significantly change the grain size of TiO2 but greatly enhanced the photocatalytic activity of the TiO2 film.The optimal doping concentration of F corresponded to F/Ti molar ratio of 0.01.The photocatalytic activity of the FTO thin film was 23% higher than that of TiO2 thin film.X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy results showed that there were two forms of F element in the FTO thin film:surface chemically adsorbed F and substituent lattice F.Both surface adsorbed F and substituent lattice F played a role in the photocatalytic activity enhancement of the FTO thin film.

0a8kRbS1.title: Preparation of an Mo and C co-doped TiO2 catalyst by a calcination-hydrothermal method, and degradation of rhodamine B in visible light
0a8kRbS1.abstract: Mo and C co-doped TiO2 photocatalysts were successfully prepared by a calcination-hydrothermal method. The catalysts were characterized by XRD, XPS, DRS, FTIR, and Raman spectroscopy. Results from photocatalysis showed that 1%Mo-C4/TiO2 had excellent visible light photocatalytic activity. This may be ascribed not only to the Mo and C doping but also to synergism between the Mo and C. © 2012 Springer Science+Business Media Dordrecht.

TlyfevvO.title: Research Progress of Photocatalytic Performance of TiO_2 Photocatalysts Modified by Nitrogen-Doping
TlyfevvO.abstract: The progresses in research on photocatalytic performance of TiO2 modified by nitrogen-doping as well as the improvement of efficiency of the photocatalyst in the visible light region are reviewed.The preparation methods,theoretical calculation and structural model,and doping mechanism of the nitrogen-doped TiO2 are discussed.The current problems and further research directions are also proposed.

iojk42Za.title: Study on the PSL mechanism in BaFCl:Eu<sup>2+</sup> phosphors
iojk42Za.abstract:
In this paper, the ESR and photoluminescence (PL) of BaFCl and BaFCl:Eu2+ radiated or un-radiated by X-ray were observed. The single electron in the color center could be produced in BaFCl without
 Eu2+. A series of traps of different energy level in BaFCl lattice were formed, and some shallow traps of them could be bleached
 by Vis-light, and the other deep traps could not. The bleaching effects on ESR and photostimulated luminescence (PSL) were
 investigated. An F-H-Eu2+ complex (F color center, H color center and Eu2+ complex) in the lattice of BaFCl:Eu2+ was suggested when the phosphor was X-ray irradiated. The Eu2+ located in the complex has only contribution to the ESR signal, but has no contribution to PL spectrum. The excitation of
 both F-center and located Eu2+ could decompose the complex to induce bleaching. The 440 nm light could excite the F-centers and the 220 nm and 270 nm could
 excite the located Eu2+, and the excitation disturbed the F-H-Eu2+ complex and caused a decrease of the PSL.

GfOD7Uop.title: Ecofriendly synthesis and photocatalytic activity of uniform cubic Ag@AgCl plasmonic photocatalyst
GfOD7Uop.abstract: Uniform cubic Ag@AgCl plasmonic photocatalyst was synthesized by a facile green route in the absence of organic solvent, in which a controllable double-jet precipitation technique was employed to fabricate homogeneous cubic AgCl grains and a photoreduction process was used to produce Ag nanoparticles (NPs) on the surface of AgCl. During the double-jet precipitation process, the presence of gelatin and Cl- ions at low concentration was necessary for the formation of cubic AgCl grains. Atomic force microscopy (AFM) was used to probe the morphological structure of Ag@AgCl grains for the first time, which showed that Ag NPs are anchored on the surface of AgCl grains like up-and-down mounds. Further characterization of the photocatalyst was also done by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and UV-visible diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS). The as-prepared Ag@AgCl plasmonic photocatalyst exhibited excellent photocatalytic efficiency for the degradation of the azo dye acid orange 7 (AO7), phenol, and 2,4-dichlorophenol (2,4-DCP). The photocatalytic mechanism was studied by radical-trapping experiments and the electron spin resonance (ESR) technique with 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline N-oxide (DMPO), and the results indicated that •O2 - and Cl0 are responsible for the rapid degradation of organic pollutants under visible-light irradiation. © 2012 American Chemical Society.

gnQR7QCJ.title: Effective visible light-active boron and carbon modified TiO2 photocatalyst for degradation of organic pollutant
gnQR7QCJ.abstract: A visible light-active TiO 2 photocatalyst modified by boron and carbon was synthesized by sol–gel followed solvothermal process. The resulting photocatalyst was characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), UV–vis absorption spectroscopy, and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR). It was found that the boron and carbon modified TiO 2 showed obvious absorption in the range 400–500 nm. XPS results suggested boron species entered into interstitial site of TiO 2 matrix and formed the B–O–Ti bond, while carbon species were in the form of carbonates species. EPR results showed the existence of oxygen vacancy in carbon and boron modified TiO 2 . This may result in the sensitivity of the as-synthesized photocatalyst to visible light. The resulting boron and carbon modified TiO 2 exhibited significantly higher photocatalytic activity than carbon modified TiO 2 and undoped anatase TiO 2 on the degradation of Acid Orange 7 (AO7) in aqueous solution under visible light irradiation. The presence of carbon originating from organic precursor has great influence on the surface properties of B-doped TiO 2 .

2M8EaOXS.title: Synthesis, characterization and application of bismuth and boron Co-doped TiO2: A visible light active photocatalyst
2M8EaOXS.abstract: Bismuth and Boron co-doped TiO2 nanoparticles were successfully prepared by a modified sol-gel method. The products were characterized with various spectroscopic and analytical techniques to determine their structural, morphological, light absorption and photocatalytic properties. The results reveal that all the samples consist of highly crystalline anatase with mesoporous structures. The experimental results further indicate that Bi and B species have been doped into the crystal lattice of TiO2 with Bi substituting Ti in the form of Bi3+ and B doped in the form of substitutional and interstitial B. The presence of Bi species facilitated the incorporation of B into the crystal lattice of TiO2. XRD and TEM analysis show that all the dopants (B and Bi) have the ability to inhibit particle growth of anatase TiO2 with more inhibition exhibited by Bi. Compared to pure TiO2, B and Bi singly doped TiO2; Bi-B co-doped samples showed better activities for degradation of Acid Orange 7 (AO7) and 2, 4-dichlorophenol under visible light irradiation. The highest activity is observed for 3% Bi-B-TiO2 calcined at 450°C. The superior performance of this sample is ascribed to the high surface area, ability to absorb in visible light, efficient charge separation as well as improved e- transfer associated with the cooperate effects of appropriate amounts of B and Bi in co-doped sample. Bi species are found to play a pivotal role in the co-doped samples. Superoxide radicals are the most reactive species in degradation of AO7 over 3% Bi-B-TiO2 under visible light irradiation. © 2012 Elsevier B.V.

7ZRUkANG.title: Self-doped Ti3+-enhanced TiO2 nanoparticles with a high-performance photocatalysis
7ZRUkANG.abstract: A series of TiO2 catalysts self-doped with Ti3+ were successfully synthesized by a simple one-step solvothermal method with low-cost NaBH4 added as a reductant. During NaBH4 reduction, large amounts of NaBO2 and carbonaceous impurities covered the surface of the TiO2 self-doped with Ti3+, resulting in an inhibition of visible-light absorption and photocatalytic activity. In the preparation, HCl solution was used to wash off the by-product NaBO2 and carbonaceous impurities coated on the surface of the catalysts. The samples were characterized by XRD, UV-DRS, ESR, XPS, and FT-IR analyses. After HCl washing, the photocatalytic activity of the Ti3+-doped TiO2 increased markedly, while the Ti3+ content remained the same. Furthermore, it was found that the visible-light photocatalytic activity of Ti3+-doped TiO2 depended on the amount of Ti3+ added, while there was no significant impact of Ti3+ doping on its UV-light photocatalytic activity. © 2012 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.

ikK8IxrM.title: Synthesis of well ordered mesoporous Yb, N co-doped TiO 2 with superior visible photocatalytic activity
ikK8IxrM.abstract: Well-ordered mesoporous TiO 2 co-doped with nitrogen and ytterbium was successfully synthesized by an evaporation-induced self-assembly process. The as-prepared and calcined mesoporous TiO 2 materials were characterized by X-ray diffraction, transmission electron microscope, UV-vis absorbance spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, fourier transform infrared and N 2 adsorption-desorption measurements. After calcinations at 350 °C, the TiO 2 co-doped with nitrogen and 3% ytterbium had the highest surface area (219 m 2 g -1) and retained ordered structures. Under visible light irradiation, 75% of 20 mg/L phenol solution was degraded after 10 h and 10 mg/L rhodamine B (RhB) was decomposed completely after 4 h. The significant enhancement in the photocatalytic activity of the modified TiO 2 is attributed to the synergistic effect of N and Yb. The N dopant extended the absorption to visible region and the Yb dopant was beneficial in stabilizing the mesoporous structure and restraining the recombination of photogenerated holes and electrons. © 2012 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.

VFHlPpbs.title: Singlet Oxygen Triggered by Superoxide Radicals in a Molybdenum Cocatalytic Fenton Reaction with Enhanced REDOX Activity in the Environment.
VFHlPpbs.abstract: As an important reactive oxygen species (ROS) with selective oxidation, singlet oxygen (1O2) has wide application prospects in biology and the environment. However, the mechanism of 1O2 formation, especially the conversion of superoxide radicals (•O2-) to 1O2, has been a great controversy. This process is often disturbed by hydroxyl radicals (•OH). Here, we develop a molybdenum cocatalytic Fenton system, which can realize the transformation from •O2- to 1O2 on the premise of minimizing •OH. The Mo0 exposed on the surface of molybdenum powder can significantly improve the Fe3+/Fe2+ cycling efficiency and weaken the production of •OH, leading to the generation of •O2-. Meanwhile, the exposed Mo6+ can realize the transformation of •O2- to 1O2. The molybdenum cocatalytic effect makes the conventional Fenton reaction have high oxidation activity for the remediation of organic pollutants and prompt the inactivation of Staphylococcus aureus, as well as the adsorption and reduction of heavy metal ions (Cu2+, Ni2+ and Cr6+). Compared with iron powder, molybdenum powder is more likely to promote the conversion from Fe3+ to Fe2+ during the Fenton reaction, resulting in a higher Fe2+/Fe3+ ratio and better activity regarding the remediation of organics. Our findings clarify the transformation mechanism from •O2- to 1O2 during the Fenton-like reaction and provide a promising REDOX Fenton-like system for water treatment.

EnbTDi3Y.title: Preparation of Ce-TiO2 catalysts by controlled hydrolysis of titanium alkoxide based on esterification reaction and study on its photocatalytic activity.
EnbTDi3Y.abstract: The Ce-TiO2 catalysts were prepared by controlled hydrolysis of Ti(OC(4)H(9))(4) with water generated "in situ" via an esterification reaction between acetic acid and ethanol, followed by hydrothermal treatment. The samples were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), atomic absorption flame emission spectroscopy (AAS), and nitrogen adsorption-desorption methods. Both of undoped TiO2 and Ce-TiO2 samples exclusively consist of primary anatase crystallites, which further form spherical aggregates with diameters ranging from 100 to 500 nm. The photocatalytic activity of Ce-TiO2 was investigated for the photocatalytic degradation of Rhodamine B (RB) aqueous solution both under UV and visible light irradiation. Doping of Ce(4+) effectively improves the photocatalytic activity under both UV light irradiation and visible light irradiation with an optimal doping concentration of 0.2 and 0.4%, respectively. The photocatalytic mechanisms of Ce-TiO2 catalysts were tentatively discussed.

pPcl1fUB.title: Synthesis of mesoporous ZSM-5 by one-pot method in the presence of polyethylene glycol
pPcl1fUB.abstract: Mesoporous ZSM-5 was synthesized by using dual templates and one step hydrothermal crystallization method under alkali conditions. Mesopores were created by using cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) as the template and the crystallized pore wall framework was formed by using tetrapropylammonium bromide (TPAB) as the template. The specific influences of the polyethylene glycol (PEG) and ammonium fluoride (NH 4 F) addition, hydrothermal crystallization temperature, TPAB/Si and Al/Si ratio to the mesostructure and crystallinity of the obtained samples were carefully studied. In this system, PEG plays an important role in the maintenance of the mesoporous pore ordering and the zeolite crystallinity. Moreover, the study on the hydrothermal stability of the sample with best mesoporous pore ordering and zeolite crystallinity showed this kind mesoporous zeolite has extremely high hydrothermal stability in boiling water.

X3TIAc2n.title: Photophysical and photochemical properties of Coumarin-6 molecules incorporated within MCM-48
X3TIAc2n.abstract: Laser dye Coumarin-6 (C6) molecules were incorporated into the three-dimensional channels of mesoporous molecular sieve MCM-48. The photophysical and photochemical properties of C6 in MCM-48 were characterized by absorption, emission and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra. The results indicated that MCM-48 exerted a significant influence on the photophysical and photochemical properties of the incorporated C6 molecules. Absorption maxima of C6 in MCM-48 exhibited large red-shift while emission exhibited relatively small red-shift compared with those in ethanol. A broad EPR signal with a g value of 2.003 indicates that electron transfer occur easily in the C6/MCM-48 composite.

W6R11BWc.title: Catalysis of redox reactions by Ag@TiO2 and Fe 3+-doped Ag@TiO2 core-shell type nanoparticles
W6R11BWc.abstract: Ag nanoparticles encapsulated by TiO2 shells have the ability to catalyze redox reactions on their surface. By continually monitoring by use of UV-visible spectroscopy it was found that the surface charge of both TiO 2-coated and uncoated colloidal silver particles changed after chemical electron injection. The charging and discharging process of Ag@TiO 2 vary, depending on the different Ag content of the core-shell nanoparticles. In order to enhance the stability of Ag@TiO2 colloids, Fe3+ was doped into the lattice of the TiO2 shells. The experimental results showed that the Fe3+ ions have the capacity to store and transfer electrons. Furthermore, the charging and discharging rate can be controlled by changing the thickness of the TiO2 shells, because they are limited by the diffusion distance of electrons through the TiO 2 shells. © Springer Science+Business Media B.V. 2010.
