a8Xtg3gs.title: Mesoporous TiO2-B nanowires synthesized from tetrabutyl titanate
a8Xtg3gs.abstract: Ultralong mesoporous TiO 2 -B nanowires were synthesized via a hybrid hydrothermal-ion exchanging-thermal treatment using tetrabutyl titanate (TBOT) as a raw material. The phase transformations and porous structures of TiO 2 -B nanowires were characterized and studied by X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and N 2 adsorption–desorption measurement. Mesoporous TiO 2 -B nanowires showed a length of several micrometers and diameter of about 25 nm. The porous structures of obtained TiO 2 -B nanowires were demonstrated by BJH pore distribution measurement. The wirelike morphologies and porous structures of monodisperse nanowires calcined at 600 °C showed little change, which indicated that such nanowires possessed high thermal stability. The formation mechanism of TiO 2 -B nanowires with mesoporous structures were also discussed based on our experimental results. Graphical abstract Research highlights ► Synthesis of ultralong mesoporous TiO 2 -B nanowires from protonated dititanate. ► Porous structures of TiO 2 -B nanowires possessed high thermal stability. ► The formation of TiO 2 -B nanowires follows the oriented attachment mechanism. Keywords A. Oxides C. Electron microscopy C. X-ray diffraction D. Microstructure 1 Introduction Titanium dioxide (TiO 2 ) is a well-known wide band-gap n-type semiconductor photocatalysts with high activities for environmental remediation such as air and water purification, water disinfection and hazardous waste degradation [1–3] . One-dimensional (1D) nanostructured titania materials, such as nanowires and nanotubes, are particularly significant due to their superior photovoltaic (solar energy conversion), photocatalytic and gas-sensing properties [4–8] . TiO 2 -B is the least dense polymorph of titania and the metastable monoclinic modification of titanium dioxide with a shear-derivative of the ReO 3 type structure. Recently, TiO 2 -B was confirmed as promising candidate anode materials exhibiting favorable electrochemical properties [9–15] . Several literatures reported that TiO 2 -B nanowires exhibited larger specific charge-storage capacity (335 mA h/g) than TiO 2 -B and anatase nanoparticles [8,9] and more excellent photocatalytic efficiency than P25 and commercial anatase nanoparticles [4] . The first synthesis of TiO 2 -B nanowires by a hydrothermal route was reported by Armstrong in 2004 [8] . Porous structure was regarded to endow nanomaterials such as nanotitania with multiple advantages, e.g. higher mass transfer ability [16] ; many attempts hence were made to prepare 1D TiO 2 and/or titanate nanostructural materials with high pore volume [16–21] . In our previous work, TiO 2 -B nanowires with the unique morphologies of pits and dislocations were synthesized via a hydrothermal-ion exchanging-thermal treatment using TiO 2 particles (Degussa P25, which consists of about 30% rutile and 70% anatase, the particle size of which is about 30 nm) as a raw material [22] . The evolvement of pits on the TiO 2 -B nanowires was elucidated in that work, which were however limited in amount and size. Several other raw materials were therefore selected to confirm whether the poor pits can be developed to a possible porous structure in the TiO 2 -B nanowires. Using tetrabutyl titanate (TBOT) as a raw material and shortening the hydrothermal treatment time, ultralong TiO 2 -B nanowires with remarkable porous structure were synthesized in this work. Compared to the previous work, TiO 2 -B nanowires obtained here had larger pore volume, smaller diameter and higher thermal stability. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials TBOT was chemically pure and obtained from Ling Feng Chemical Reagent. NaOH (analytical reagent) and hydrochloric acid (analytical reagent) were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent. All the reagents were used as received. Doubly distilled water was used throughout the work. 2.2 Synthesis of TiO 2 -B nanowires Hydrogen titanate nanowires were synthesized in advance by an alkaline solvothermal-ion exchanging treatment. In a typical procedure, 7.0 ml tetrabutyl titanate (TBOT) was directly added and compulsively hydrolyzed in the 10 M aqueous solution of NaOH under vigorously stirring. The total volume of solution was controlled up to 75 ml. After stirring for about several minutes the resulting suspension was transferred to a teflon-lined autoclave and heated to 180 °C for 24 h. After hydrothermal treatment, the product was acid-washed, which involved stirring the sample in 0.1 M HCl solution for 6 h in order to remove the residual Na + ion completely. The material was then filtered, washed with distilled water, and dried at 50 °C for 24 h. In order to investigate the phase transformation and morphology evolution of the product at the conditions of post-heat treatment, the acid-washed product was also calcined at 300, 400, 600, 800 and 1000 °C for 4 h in air, respectively. Consequently, pure TiO 2 -B nanowires were prepared by heating the acid-washed product at 400 °C for 4 h in air. 2.3 Characterization XRD patterns were obtained using a powder diffractometer (RIGAKU D/max2550) operating in the reflection mode with CuKα radiation at a scan rate of 0.02° (2 θ s −1 ). The morphology of the collected powders was investigated using a high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM, JEOL JEM-2100 F) operated at 200 kV and equipped with EDX facilities. To prepare the HRTEM specimens, the powder samples were first dispersed ultrasonically in anhydrous ethanol. One drop of the suspension was placed on a carbon film supported on a copper grid and allowed to dry in air before the specimens were transferred into the microscope. Specific surface areas were determined using an ASAP 2020 Micromeritics apparatus following the BET analysis. Adsorption and desorption of N 2 were performed at −196 °C. Samples had been previously outgassed by heating at 100 °C under vacuum (3 mm Hg). Desorption isotherm was used to determine the pore size distribution using the Barret–Joyner–Halender (BJH) method. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Phase transition and morphological transformation during TiO 2 -B nanowires synthesis Phase transition and morphological transformation of TiO 2 -B nanowires were characterized by XRD and TEM, respectively. Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of sodium titanate, acid-washed titanate and the calcined samples. Fig. 1 a gives a XRD pattern, which is very similar to the structural configuration of sodium trititanate; hence, the precise formula of sodium titanate can be denoted as Na 2 Ti 3 O 7 · n H 2 O. After H + ion-exchange, the most intense peak of the titanate structure at 2 θ ≈10°, which should be ascribed to the (0 0 1) crystal plane shifts to high-angle ( Fig. 1 b), suggesting that the layer spaces of titanates were narrowed as a result of the interlayered Na + ions replaced by hydroniums (H 3 O + ions). The structure of acid-washed product can be identified as the layered hydrogen titanate H 2 Ti 3 O 7 · n H 2 O [23] . Layered hydrogen titanate would be converted to TiO 2 -B, anatase or rutile polymorph with the increase in calcined temperatures [24] . The calcined product of layered hydrogen titanate at 300 °C ( Fig. 1 c) should be identified as the TiO 2 -B phase. TiO 2 -B can be readily distinguished from the anatase structure by the absence of the anatase peak at 37° (0 0 4) and from the titanate structure by its broad peak of multiple planes between 28° and 34° and by the absence of the trititanate (0 0 1) peak at about 10° [25] . The main diffraction peaks ( Fig. 1 d) of the nanowires obtained in the typical procedure (400 °C) are 14.18°, 24.96°, 28.62° and 48.44°, which correspond well to the (0 0 1), (1 1 0), (0 0 2) and (0 2 0) lattice planes of TiO 2 -B [26,27] . Besides the lattice planes of TiO 2 -B, the obvious diffraction peaks at 25.22°, 36.86°, 37.72° and 38.64° presented in Fig. 1 e, which correspond to the (1 0 1), (1 0 3), (0 0 4) and (1 1 2) lattice planes of anatase, indicate the coexistence of TiO 2 -B and anatase at 600 °C and the further development of phase transformation. Fig. 1 f gives a normal XRD pattern of anatase, which means a thorough transformation from TiO 2 -B to anatase at 800 °C. Finally, Fig. 1 g shows the sample calcined at 1000 °C to be pure rutile. In a word, the as-prepared hydrogen titanate exhibited the following phase transformation process during the thermal treatment: hydrogen titanate→TiO 2 -B (300–400 °C)→TiO 2 -B and anatase (600 °C)→anatase (800 °C)→ rutile (1000 °C). Fig. 2 shows the TEM (a) and HRTEM (b) images of the sodium titanate nanowires. Fig. 2 a shows the ultralong sodium titanate nanowires with the length of several micrometers. Fig. 2 b shows that the fringe spacings of 0.356 and 0.832 nm correspond to the (0 1 1) and (0 0 1) lattice planes of Na 2 Ti 3 O 7 , indicating the layered structures of sodium titanate nanowires. Fig. 3 a–c shows the TEM images of nanowires calcined at 300 °C ( Fig. 3 a) and 400 °C ( Fig. 3 b and c). The sample calcined at 300 °C is an ultralong nanowire, which is presented in Fig. 3 a. The length of the single nanowire is several micrometers, but the diameter of a single nanowire is only about 25 nm. In addition, it is noted that the surface of nanowires are not slick so that the coarse profile indicates the incompact configurations of nanowires. The nanowire obtained at 400 °C ( Fig. 3 b) gives a similar size (diameter of about 25 nm) as those of the hydrogen titanate nanowires and the sample calcined at 300 °C, which means no obvious size growth occurred. It is worthwhile to note that a great deal of pores with an average size of about 4 nm is presented throughout the nanowires ( Fig. 3 b). Hence, the TiO 2 -B nanowires synthesized from TBOT have higher length–diameter ratio and more compact porous structures. The porous morphologies and the size of TiO 2 -B nanowires are clearly presented in the magnified TEM image of Fig. 3 c, in which the diameter of such nanowires is about 20–30 nm and pores with the size of about 3–5 nm are well distributed in the nanowires. In our previous work, the diameter of TiO 2 -B nanowires synthesized from P25 was about 50 nm, which is duple to the TiO 2 -B nanowires obtained in the current work [22] . The corresponding SAED pattern of nanowires calcined at 400 °C are located in the bottom right inset of Fig. 3 c. The central spot is shaded in the pattern in order to give better visibility of diffraction spots. Since the diffraction spots linked in lines can be observed, the linear spacings of 0.358 nm corresponds to the (1 1 0) lattice planes of TiO 2 -B. Fig. 3 d is the HRTEM image of nanowires calcined at 400 °C. Fringe spacings of 0.317, 0.364 and 0.636 nm correspond well to the (0 0 2), (1 1 0) and (0 0 1) lattice planes of TiO 2 -B. The linear diffraction spots shown in SAED pattern ( Fig. 3 c, the inset) and the imperfect lattice fringes ( Fig. 3 d) exhibit the porous structure of TiO 2 -B, which disorders some the crystalline structure of TiO 2 -B nanowires. 3.2 Specific surface area and pore size distribution of TiO 2 -B nanowires The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms and (BJH) pore size distribution curves (inset) of the layered hydrogen titanates (hollow circles) and TiO 2 -B nanowires (solid circles) are presented in Fig. 4 . The hydrogen titanate nanowire gives an S BET of 23.65 m 2 /g, and does not show a special pore size distribution in the range 1.8–10 nm. The hysteresis loop at the relative pressure of P / P 0 >0.8 is associated with the pores of size larger than 10 nm, which can be attributed to the intra-aggregate pore of the nanowires [28] . A distinct capillary condensation step can be clearly seen in the nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherm of the TiO 2 -B nanowires, giving an S BET of 38.33 m 2 /g, which is larger than the one ever reported [22] . The hysteresis loop is associated with pores that have a maximum distribution at a pore size of about 4.2 nm ( Fig. 4 , inset), corresponding to the unique morphologies of mesoporous structures at TiO 2 -B nanowires. The pore volume of TiO 2 -B nanowires at 4.2 nm of 0.0884 cm 3 /g is much greater than that of the TiO 2 -B reported in our previous work, indicating that the pore volume is greater than that of products synthesized from P25 [22] . The increased surface area of TiO 2 -B nanowire from the hydrogen titanate nanowire may be partly attributed to the formation of mesoporous structures on TiO 2 -B nanowires. Fig. 5 shows the TEM images of nanowires calcined at 600 °C ( Fig. 5 a and b), 800 °C ( Fig. 5 c) and 1000 °C ( Fig. 5 d). Fig. 5 a indicates that the diameter of single nanowire is maintained at 25–30 nm. In Fig. 5 b, mesopores at nanowires have been further enlarged and the pore size increases to more than 10–20 nm at a temperature of 600 °C, which indicates that the monodisperse nanowires combined mesoporous structures possessed high thermal stability. Samples obtained at 800 °C ( Fig. 5 c) also maintain 1D structure, and the subsistence of two holes in the rod indicates that porous structures existing in the nanowires and pores have merged together with the increase in calcined temperatures. The diameter of the nanowires is more than 100 nm, indicating that the aggregation and size growth of the nanowires occurred at 800 °C. The crystalline phase of sample has completely converted into anatase, and the perfect lattice fringes without any distortions are captured by the HRTEM image located in the top right inset of Fig. 5 c. The square area magnified in the inset clearly shows that fringe spacings of 0.354 nm precisely correspond to the (1 0 1) lattice planes of anatase, indicating that single crystalline nanorods have been produced. Finally, nanowires calcined at 1000 °C ( Fig. 5 d) show the submicron rod-like structure of rutile. 3.3 Formation mechanism of TiO 2 -B nanowires The formation of TiO 2 -B nanowires with mesoporous structure could be elucidated by the oriented attachment mechanism, which was also proposed in our previous work [22] . The ion-exchange of sodium ions with H + raises internal stress in the interlayers of hydrogen titanate. Numerous works reported that the protonation of sodium dititanate resulted in the convolution of dititanate nanosheets, namely the formation of hydrogen dititanate nanotubes [29] . However, such a convolution is impossible in the hydrogen titanate nanowire of diameter 25 nm in this work; the upheaval of internal stress during the ion-exchange results in the cataclasm of titanate layer. Therefore, the hydrogen titanate nanowires can be considered as the accumulation of primary crystalline units, among which a great number of vacancies exist. The transformation from hydrogen titanate to TiO 2 -B involves an exothermic nucleation and growth step, which results in the formation of a TiO 2 -B-like intermediate. The final TiO 2 -B is formed by a low energy transformation from the intermediate [30] . During the thermal treatment, the reduction of the overall surface energy by eliminating the interface of units drives the oriented attachment [31,32] . Therefore, when the nanowires are calcined at 400 °C, the vacancies are enlarged by the rearrangement of the primary crystalline units, which leads to the porous structures formed in the TiO 2 -B nanowires. According to the oriented attachment mechanism, the larger single crystallites (nanowires) are then formed due to slight rotation and merging of many small crystallites; consequently the pore size is enlarged with the increase in calcined temperatures. Mesopores at nanowires can be further enlarged to a size of more than 10–20 nm at 600 °C, and are eliminated at 800 °C to form the single crystallite of anatase nanorods. Using TBOT as a raw material can obtain an improved and remarkable porous structure in TiO 2 -B nanowires compared to the raw material of P25. A probable reason should be ascribed to the different formation kinetics of the sodium titanate nanowires. Once TBOT was compulsorily hydrolyzed in the alkaline solution (NaOH), amorphous titanate was formed by condensing TiO 6 octahedral monomers [33] . The formation of sodium titanate nanowires with high crystallization are thus synthesized by the rearrangement of the amorphous titanate. However, P25 consists of about 30% rutile and 70% anatase, and is highly crystallized. The synthesis of sodium titanate should be synthesized based on the mechanism of dissolution–crystallization at hydrothermal treatment, which process is relatively slower than that of TBOT. Consequently, the sodium titanate nanowires obtained from P25 have a larger size and stronger strength, which result in larger splinters (larger primary crystalline units) when the crash of titanate layer occurs. Using TBOT as a raw material, the primary crystalline units with very small size and more regular distributions could be formed in the acid washing process, which transforms to a remarkable mesoporous structure with higher pore volume in the process of post-heat treatment. 4 Conclusion Ultralong TiO 2 -B nanowires were synthesized via a hybrid hydrothermal-ion exchanging-thermal treatment using TBOT as a raw material. Once TBOT was compulsorily hydrolyzed in the aqueous solution of NaOH, amorphous titanate was formed by condensing TiO 6 octahedral monomers. Ultralong sodium titanate nanowires with high crystallization were synthesized in the hydrothermal process by the rearrangement of amorphous titanate. A mesoporous TiO 2 -B nanowires with a length of several micrometers and diameter of about 25 nm were obtained in the process of post-heat treatment, which had a maximum distribution at a pore size of 4.2 nm, and gives an S BET of 38.33 m 2 /g, were demonstrated by TEM images and BJH pore distribution measurement. The wirelike morphologies and porous structures of monodisperse nanowires calcined at 600 °C showed little change, which indicated that such nanowires possessed high thermal stability. Acknowledgments This work was supported by the National Nature Science Foundation of China ( 20777015 ) and the National Basic Research Program of China ( 2007CB613301 and 2010CB732306 ). VDUOTrDR.title: F− assistant synthesis of ultra-hydrothermally stable mesoporous silica by using nonionic organosilicon surfactant as templates
VDUOTrDR.abstract: Mesoporous silica with thick pore wall (designated ECT) was synthesized in the presence of fluoride anions by using nonionic organosilicon surfactant (K903) as template. According to the results from XRD patterns and N 2 adsorption–desorption analysis, the addition of fluoride has a strong effect on the pore diameter and pore wall thickness of the ECT samples. 29 Si MAS NMR indicates that the degree of silicate condensation is greatly enhanced by adding fluoride ions. The hydrothermal stability of the mesoporous silica (ECT) synthesized in the presence of fluoride was found to be greatly improved compared to that of the sample without addition of fluoride ions. When F/Si = 0.045, the mesostructure of the sample could still remain after refluxed in boiling water even for 20 days. The ultra hydrothermal stability could be attributed to its thick pore wall, less defects in the silica framework and high degree of polymerization of silicate. Moreover, results from SEM reveal that the addition of fluoride anions also has great effect on the morphology structure of ECT sample. Keywords ECT Hydrothermal stability Mesoporous Fluoride Polymethylsiloxane 1 Introduction Since MCM-41 was firstly reported by Mobil [1] in 1992, many research works have been focused on synthesis [2,3] , characterization [4] and application [5–7] of mesostructure materials. One of the most important usages of mesoporous material is as organic synthesis catalyst or the catalyst carrier [8,9] . Because many organic reactions must be carried in aqueous solution and even in steam at high temperature [10] , most of the mesoporous structure would be destroyed during the reaction process due to its amorphous silica wall. The poor hydrothermal stability of mesoporous materials limits its future industry application. Many works have been done to overcome this drawback, such as silylation [11,12] , incorporation of hetero-atom [13–16] , addition of inorganic salt [17,18] , using silica nanosphere as framework [19] and transferring zeolite to mesoporous material [20] . Besides the above improvements, addition of fluoride ions is considered as an effective and convenient method to improve the hydrothermal stability. Wang et al. reported that the hydrothermal stability of MCM-48 was conveniently and effectively improved by increasing the crystallization temperature and directly adding NaF to the synthesis gel [21] . As for SBA-15 kind materials, the polymerization degree was found to be the main factor that influences their hydrothermal stability. Zhao et al. employed a carbon-propping and high temperature thermal treatment approach to increase the polymerization degree [22] . This approach showed superior hydrothermal stability in pure steam of 1073 K for 12 h. Generally, mesoporous silica with thicker pore wall is more resistant to the boiling water since although the boiling water appears to gradually peel off the surface layers of silica, the removal of slim layer does not compromise the integrity of the framework [23] . For examples, Jin et al. has synthesized highly ordered SBA-16-type mesoporous silica with thick pore wall by using F108 through two-steps pathway under mildly acidic conditions [24] . Cho et al. reported that hydrothermal stable mesoporous ethanesilica was synthesized through macromolecular templating approach [25] . The mesoporous structural integrity of the solvent-extract sample was maintained for up to 25 days in boiling water at 373 K. But the used macromolecular template (nonionic PEO-PLGA-PEO triblock copolymer) is not commercially available. Recently, our group has synthesized ordered 2-D hexagonal mesoporous silica (ECT) with ultra-thick pore wall from nonionic organosilicon surfactant [26] . Compared with other hexagonal mesoporous silica (MCM-41), the ECT sample has excellent hydrothermal stability due to its thick pore wall. However the used surfactant contains organosilica component. It is difficult to form compact mesoporous silica wall during calcination process. In this study, we added different contents of fluoride ions into the previous synthesis system in order to accelerate the hydrolyze rate and enhance the level of polymerization of silicate species. The hydrothermal stability of fluorinated mesoporous ECT samples in boiling water has been studied by using the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The reactants used in this study were the tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS) as a silica source, sodium fluoride as a fluorine source, K903 as a surfactant, hydrochloric acid solution and deionized water. 2.2 Experimental procedure The fluorinated mesoporous silica molecular sieve (designated ECT) was synthesized as follows: nonionic organosilicon surfactant (K903) was dissolved in hydrochloric acid solution with vigorous stirring. Different amounts of sodium fluoride were added to the above mixture solution. At 309 K, a certain amount of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) was slowly added into the above mixture solution. After being added, the mixture was stirred for another 2 h. The mother gel composition was K903:HCl:H 2 O:TEOS:NaF = 1:146:5294:20.6: x , where x = 0, 0.023, 0.045, 0.09, 0.18, 0.36. The resulting mixture was crystallized under static hydrothermal conditions at 393 K in a Teflon bottle for 24 h. The precipitate was recovered by filtration, washed with distilled water and air-dried in air overnight. The as-synthesized samples were calcined at 823 K in a flow of air for 5 h to remove the organic composite of the template. 2.3 Hydrothermal stability test The calcined sample (0.1 g) was boiled at 373 K for different period of time in 100 ml of double-distilled water by using a flask equipped with reflux condenser. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were used to assess the hydrothermal stability. 2.4 Characterization X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns of all samples were recorded on Rigaku D/MAX-2550 diffractometer using Cu Ka radiation of wavelength 1.54056 Å, typically running at a voltage of 40 kV and current of 100 mA. N 2 adsorption and desorption isotherms were carried out by using Micromeritics ASAP 2010. For BET (Brunauer–Emmett–Teller method), the as-synthesized samples were calcined following the procedures described in experimental section and the samples were then outgassed to remove moistures and impurities at 623 K for 5 h before measurement. 29 Si NMR spectra were measured using a Bruker DMX 40 instrument. Data were obtained at 79.45 MHz with 90° pluses and 100 s recycle delays zrconia rotors 4 mm in diameter spun at 5 kHz. The chemical shifts are given in ppm from external tetramethysilane (TMS). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was performed on JEOL JSM-6360 LV. The instrument employed for XPS studies was VG ESCALab MK Surface Analysis System (UK) with MgK radiation ( hυ = 1253.6 eV) operated at 300 W. Raman spectra were recorded on the inVia Reflex spectrometer equipped with an optical microscope at ambient temperature. For excitation, the 785 nm line from an Ar + ion laser was focused. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD and XRS analysis The content of fluoride in the synthesis system is defined as the mole ratio of F/Si. ECT samples with different F − contents were synthesized to study the effect of fluoride on the quality and hydrothermal stability of ECT mesoporous materials. According to Fig. 1 , all the ECT samples exhibits only one diffraction peak. When the F/Si ratio is low (F/Si = 0.023, 0.045 and 0.090), the peak intensity increases and the width of the peak becomes narrow compared with that of pure mesoporous silica. It indicates that the presence of small amount of fluoride is beneficial to the formation of mesopores, which is in agreement with other report [27] . Table 1 shows that the pore size increases and the pore wall thickness decreases with the addition of fluoride ions with F/Si = 0.023. However, the pore size and the pore wall thickness gradually increase with the increasing F/Si ratio. These results can be explained as follows: The addition of fluoride ions into the synthesis system leads to the enlargement of the surfactant micelle [28] . Moreover, the addition of fluoride will also lead to the formation of Si–F bonds and a progressive decrease of hydroxyl groups on silica oligomers. The amount of silanol groups on the outer shell became fewer and more non-silicates regions were created. It is difficult for silicate oligomers to hydrolyze in deep region of the hydrophilic shell. So the pore size increases and the wall thickness decreases at F/Si = 0.023. However, the addition of fluoride ions can also accelerate the silicates polymerization. So, when the F/Si ratios further increase, the wall thickness gradually increases. As a result, with the increase of the fluoride amount, a 0 lattice value increases from 88.3 Å (F/Si = 0.023) to 102.7 Å (F/Si = 0.360). The increase of the F/Si ratio will also destruct the pore ordering of ECT. As seen from Fig. 1 , the structure ordering of the samples synthesized at F/Si = 0.180 and 0.360 drastically degrade. It can be attributed to the overfast polymerization rate of the silicates species accelerated by the large amount free fluoride anions in the synthesis medium, leading to the deterioration of the pore ordering [29] . Similar studies have been shown in the literature in which high quality SBA-15 could not be obtained with F/Si > 0.05 [30] . The data of XPS in Table 1 shows that the fluorine contents of the samples synthesized at 0.023, 0.045, 0.09, 0.18 and 0.36 are 1.17%, 1.21%, 1.57%, 1.23% and 1.13%, respectively. On the condition of low F/Si ratio (0.023, 0.045, 0.09), the fluorine content on the pore surface increases with the increase of the adding amount of F − . However the fluorine contents of the samples synthesized at F/Si = 0.18 and 0.36 are lower than that of the samples synthesized at F/Si = 0.09. Overfast polymerization of silicate species make fewer F − ions participate in the fabrication of pore channels. F − ions tend to remain in the solution, not the surface of micelles. 3.2 N 2 adsorption–desorption isotherms The addition of fluoride anions also has strong effect on the pore diameter and the pore wall thickness. As long range ordering of ECT mesoporous samples is kept at low F/Si ratio, the introduction of fluoride can be considered as an effective method to control the pore property of mesoporous material. The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms of calcined ECT samples with and without different fluoride contents are shown in Fig. 2 , which exhibits a type IV isotherm with a H 2 type hysteresis loop. The sharp step in the isotherm reflects the uniform mesopores in all the samples. Table 1 shows that the mean pore diameter of mesoporous silica increases with the increasing F − concentration in the synthesis medium. It can be explained by its catalytic oxolation properties: the more fluoride added, the faster the oxolation reaction proceeds [31] . The surfactant micelle is formed with a central hydrophobic core made of polymethylsiloxane and a hydrophilic shell. The addition of fluoride will lead to the formation of Si–F bonds and a progressive decrease of hydroxyl groups on silica oligomers. The silica framework which was reticulated on the outer shell by silica oligomers appeared to become more difficult to be linked with hydrolyzed silicate species. Silica oligomers can not enter deeply into the hydrophilic shell, which increases non-silicates region. The more fluoride ions are added, the less silicate species exist in the deep region of the outer shell. During the calcination process, the polymethylsiloxane groups will link with the hydroxyl groups of silica oligomers in the hydrophilic shell. Therefore, the mesopores of all the samples expand from 3.21 to 4.34 nm with the increase of adding fluoride amount. When F/Si ratios are increased above 0.090, the hydrolysis rate of silica species is so fast that silica oligomers can not reach into the outer shell and quickly aggregated on the reticulated silica layer. Therefore, the pore wall thickness of the samples (F/Si = 0.090, 0.180 and 0.360) remained almost the same (about 6 nm). 3.3 XRD analysis of the samples after hydrothermal stability test Fig. 3 shows that XRD patterns of calcined ECT samples with different fluoride amount after being boiled in water at 373 K for various times. According to the literature [26] , the pure mesoporous silica synthesized by using nonionic organosilicon surfactant lost its pore structure after being boiled for 3 days. By adding fluoride ions, the hydrothermal stability of ECT mesoporous silica has been drastically enhanced. When F/Si ≦ 0.090, the mesostructure of the samples can be kept after treated in boiling water at 373 K for at least 5 days. Although the pore wall of the mesoporous samples ECT with addition of fluorides is thinner than that of pure mesoporous silica, the hydrothermal stability of fluorinated ECT samples are enhanced. In the previous reference, Koyano et al. [32] explained high hydrothermal stability of silylated-calcined mesoporous molecular sieve. They divided Si–O–Si bonds in the silylated-calcined samples into three types with different stability against hydrolysis: (1) Si–O–Si bonds originally present and constituting the wall; (2) those that were formed by the trimethylsilylation; (3) those derived from condensation of trimethylsilyl groups or a trimethylsilyl group and a silanol group on calcination. Only the hydrolysis of Type 1 bonds will cause the collapse of the mesophase structure. In our system, we considered that mesoporous material was silylated in hydrothermal crystallization process. The calcination process may cause condensation of polysiloxane or polysiloxane and silanol groups. The formed Si–O–Si layer protected Type 1 bonds constituting the pore wall. In pure mesoporous silica ECT, the condensation is incomplete and some silanol groups will be generated. The addition of fluoride ions can improve this condensation, which increase the amount of Type 2 Si–O–Si bonds. The ultra-high hydrothermal stability of the fluorinated mesoporous samples can be explained by the above reason. As seen in Fig. 3 , the sample synthesized at F/Si = 0.045 exhibits the highest hydrothermal stability. The mesoporous structure of this sample was not completely lost even after being refluxed in boiling water for 20 days. Too high fluoride content in the synthesis medium is disadvantageous to the hydrothermal stability of meseporous ECT sample. Although the mesoporous samples synthesized at F/Si ≧ 0.090 have thicker pore wall, they have poor hydrothermal stability. It is because too fast silica polymerization causes more defects in the pore structure. We found that the sample with F/Si = 0.023 had less fluoride amount, but its XRD peak intensity reduced more quickly. It could be attributed to the less Si–OH groups replaced by Si–F groups and the low level of compactness of mesopore wall. Based on the experimental results, we can make a conclusion that the optimum adding fluoride amount for the formation of high hydrothermal stable mesoporous ECT is F/Si = 0.045. 3.4 Framework structure analysis We previously reported that the pure mesoporous silica ECT sample showed large shrinkage (17.8%) upon calcination, which means that the polymerization degree of silicate is low. If we found a suitable method to enhance the compactness of the pore wall, the hydrothermal stability of mesoporous ECT would be greatly improved. Fig. 4 shows the 29 Si MAS NMR spectra of calcined ECT samples with and without different F/Si ratios (F/Si = 0, 0.023, 0.045, 0.090, 0.180 and 0.360). It is observed that the ECT sample without addition of fluoride exhibits three resonances at −92, −101 and −110 ppm, assigned respectively to Q 2 , Q 3 and Q 4 (which stand for [Si(OSi) 2 (OH) 2 ], [Si(OSi) 3 (OH)] and [Si(OSi) 4 ] species) [33] . Here Q stands for a silicon atom bonded to four oxygen atoms forming a SiO 4 tetrahedron and the subscript n indicates the number of other Q units attached to this unit. When the F/Si ratio was at 0.045, it is obvious that this ratio is much higher than that of pure ECT sample. Therefore, we can make a conclusion that addition of fluoride ions can enhance the polymerization degree of silicates. All the fluorinated samples have similar level of silica polymerization. However, as seen from Fig. 3 , the different hydrothermal stabilities of the fluorinated samples can be explained as follows: At low fluoride content, more Type 2 Si–O–Si bonds and Si–F bonds with high binding energy improve the resistant ability of the framework to the water attack. At higher fluoride content, more defects were formed in the pore wall due to fast hydrolyze rate of silicate species, which is not beneficial to the hydrothermal stability. As shown in Fig. 5 , Raman spectra indicates that there is a new band centered at 945 cm −1 in fluorinated sample (F/Si = 0.045) compared with the sample without adding NaF. This new band is attributed to vibration of Si–F according to the previous literature [34] . Because the binding energy of Si–F bonds is larger than that of Si–O bonds, it is difficult for Si–F to be broken. These “tough” bonds on the pore surface can protect silanol groups from the attack of water molecules. The hydrothermal stability of mesoporous silica can be improved by the formation of these Si–F bonds. 3.5 SEM analysis Fig. 6 presents scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of ECT samples without and with the addition of fluorides (F/Si = 0.09). It is clear that the addition of fluoride ions can influence the morphology of mesoporous ECT. The pure mesoporous ECT is made of irregular mass particles with relative smooth surface. When sodium fluoride was added, the morphology was changed to a bundle of ropes with rough surface. This rough surface is beneficial to be resistant to the attack of water molecules, which makes the sample more hydrothermally stable. 4 Conclusions This report shows that high hydrothermally stable mesoporous silica was synthesized from nonionic organosilicon surfactant by adding certain amount of sodium fluoride. The long range ordering of mesoporous structure can be improved, when the F/Si ≦ 0.090. Excess fluorides caused the replacement of silanol groups and the incomplete polymerization, which is disadvantageous to the formation of high quality mesoporous ECT. Additionally, the optimal condition for hydrothermal stability is F/Si ratio of 0.045. The mesostructure of this sample can be remained even after being refluxed in boiling water at 373 K for 20 days. The high hydrothermal stability can be explained by considering that the fluorinated mesoporous ECT has fluorinated surface, ultra-thick pore wall, less defects in the silica framework and highly condensed silica wall. With the increasing amount of fluoride, the mean pore diameter and wall thickness of mesoporous samples increases. It can be explained by the catalytic oxolation properties of fluorides. 29 Si MAS NMR indicates that the addition of fluoride ions enhances the polymerization degree of silicate species. The addition of fluoride ions also has great influence on the morphology of mesoporous ECT sample. This hydrothermally stable mesoporous material is expected to be suitable for various applications in aqueous medium, such as organic catalysis, ions exchange and adsorbent. 0uWvGook.title: Tailored preparation of titania with controllable phases of anatase and brookite by an alkalescent hydrothermal route
0uWvGook.abstract: Titanium dioxide (TiO2) with different ratio of anatase to brookite has been selectively synthesized by an alkalescent hydrothermal treatment of TiCl3 in the presence of different concentration of NaCl. The resulting powders have been characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), photoluminescence (PL) analysis, UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS), and Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) analysis. The contents of anatase and brookite have been successfully controlled by adjusting the NaCl concentration and NH4OH/H 2O volume ratio. The photocatalytic activity of TiO2 has been assessed by the degradation of Rhodamine B in aqueous solution. The mixed-phase TiO2 exhibits higher activity than pure phase TiO 2, and the product containing 53.4% brookite and 46.6% anatase shows the highest photocatalytic activity. This behavior is explained by the mixed-phase effect between anatase and brookite. A proposed formation process is discussed to interpret the evolution of the phases based on the effects of different NaCl concentration and NH4OH/H2O volume ratio. © 2012 Elsevier B.V.

b70MkwsU.title: The study of visible light active bismuth modified nitrogen doped titanium dioxide photocatlysts: Role of bismuth
b70MkwsU.abstract: Bismuth modified nitrogen doped TiO2 nanoparticles have been successfully prepared by two steps synthesis route which includes hydrothermal and impregnation hydrolysis method. Samples were characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 physical adsorption, Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV-vis DRS), Fourier Transmission Infrared (FTIR), Raman, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and photoluminescence spectroscopy (PLS) technologies. The preparatory method afforded the production of well crystallized spherical Bi modified N-doped TiO2 nanoparticles with varied amounts of Bi content. XRD analysis results reveal that Bi exists as rare metastable Bi20TiO32 which started to surface at Bi loading content of 7 mol% in relation to Ti ions. All Bi modified N-TiO2 samples exhibited higher photocatalytic activity toward degradation of 2,4-DCP over N-TiO2 under visible light irradiation. The sample with 10% composition of the Bi 20TiO32 exhibited the highest activity. The superior photocatalytic performance of 10%Bi/N-TiO2 is attributed to high visible light absorption as well as effective charge carrier separation. Therefore, the role of Bi species in the N-TiO2 is improvement of visible light harvesting and facilitation of charge carrier separation hence alleviating electron-hole recombination. © 2012 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

HJlX1k5E.title: Synthesis of MCM-48 mesoporous molecular sieve with thermal and hydrothermal stability with the aid of promoter anions
HJlX1k5E.abstract: MCM-48 mesoporous molecular sieve with thermal and hydrothermal stability can be conveniently prepared within only 24 h with the aid of promoter anions SO 4 2 - , NO 3 - or Cl − (referred as P). The influences of the P/Si ratio and OH − /Si ratio to the formation of MCM-48 were investigated here, where the P/Si and OH − /Si ranges were set between 0–0.3 and 0.45–0.55, respectively. The suitable P/Si range for the formation of MCM-48 mainly depends on the hydration energy of the promoter anion, which follows the order of SO 4 2 - > Cl - > NO 3 - . The lower the hydration energy is, the wider the P/Si range is. Moreover, the P/Si range also varies with the OH − /Si, which is wider when the OH − /Si is lower. The thermal and hydrothermal stability of MCM-48 can be considerably improved by directly adding promoter anions to the synthesis gel. The results show SO 4 2 - is the most effective promoter for the improvement of structure stability due to its extremely high hydration energy, which is followed by NO 3 - and Cl − successively. Each promoter added to the synthesis gel has an optimum P/Si ratio for the improvement of the stability since overmuch addition of promoters obstructs the electronic interaction between anion silicates and cation surfactants, leading to the formation of poor ordered MCM-48 materials.

SZjjzKD9.title: Microemulsion-mediated solvothermal synthesis and photocatalytic properties of crystalline titania with controllable phases of anatase and rutile.
SZjjzKD9.abstract: Titanium oxide with different ratios of anatase to rutile has been prepared by the microemulsion-mediated solvothermal method. The resulting samples were investigated by X-ray diffraction, Raman spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy, UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra, transmission electron microscopy and Brunauer-Emmett-Teller analysis. The contents of anatase and rutile in the TiO(2) particles have been successfully controlled by simply adjusting the amount of urea in the aqueous phase of the microemulsion. Both the degradation of Rhodamine B in aqueous solutions and mineralization of TOC revealed that the catalyst containing 47.6% anatase have presented the highest photocatalytic activity. A proposed mechanism is discussed to interpret the evolution of the phases based on the effect of different amount of urea.

OYhtKMBN.title: Removal and degradation pathway study of sulfasalazine with Fenton-like reaction.
OYhtKMBN.abstract: The Fenton-like degradation of sulfasalazine solution is studied in this work. The effects of reaction parameters such as Fe(3+) concentration, initial H(2)O(2) dosage and the reaction temperature are evaluated. For sulfasalazine of 100mg/L, the removal of sulfasalazine, chemical oxygen demand (COD) and total organic carbon (TOC) reached 99.5%, 84.2% and 41% in 60 min with 0.20mM Fe(3+) and 16 mM H(2)O(2) at 35°C, respectively. The complexed Fe(3+) presents a reaction constant of 0.062 min(-1)mM(-1) while that of free Fe(3+) is 2.526 min(-1)mM(-1) for sulfasalazine degradation. LC-MS technology was used to analysis the possible degradation intermediates. The degradation of sulfasalazine principally begins with the attack of hydroxyl radical on the azo-group as well as the sulfanilamido group. Both intramolecular rearrangement and bimolecular reaction occur simultaneously after the hydroxyl radical attack. Further attack of the active oxidative species results in the cleavage of the aromatic rings and the production of CO(2). The degradation of industrial sulfasalazine wastewater with a COD of 3425 mg/L has also been achieved by Fenton reaction with different dosage of H(2)O(2). Relatively better removal efficiency is observed at moderate Fe/H(2)O(2) molar ratio from 1/5 to 2/5 for industrial sulfasalazine wastewater treatment.

sPddX4vH.title: Thermally stable SiO2-doped mesoporous anatase TiO2 with large surface area and excellent photocatalytic activity.
sPddX4vH.abstract: A thermally stable SiO(2)-doped mesoporous TiO(2) with high crystallinity was prepared by a templating method. The content of SiO(2) dopant was varied from 3% to 20%. The gels were characterized by TG-DTA analysis. And the resultant catalysts were investigated by various physicochemical techniques, such as WAXRD, Raman spectroscopy, N(2) adsorption-desorption, TEM, FT-IR, and XPS. The WAXRD, TEM, and Raman measurements suggest that the SiO(2) dopant can enhance the thermal stability of the anatase phase remarkably. Rutile phase did not present at all even at 1000 degrees C when the SiO(2) content was up to 15%. N(2) adsorption-desorption results show that the SiO(2)-doped samples have uniform pore diameters and large specific surface area, which is beneficial for photocatalytic reaction. The photocatalytic activities of the samples were evaluated by degradation of Rhodamin-6G solution under UV irradiation. The results show that the SiO(2)-doped mesoporous TiO(2) have better activity than commercial P25. Especially, the 15% SiO(2)-doped mesoporous TiO(2) exhibited much higher photocatalytic activity than P25 in a large range of calcination temperatures, even at 900 degrees C. The excellent photocatalytic activity of the samples can be attributed to the high anatase crystallinity, large specific surface area, preserved surface hydroxyl groups and mesoporous channels.

NY3n3ygx.title: Preparation and photocatalytic properties of Fe3+-doped Ag@TiO2 core-shell nanoparticles.
NY3n3ygx.abstract: Ag@TiO2 core-shell-type nanophotocatalysts have been prepared using a simple and convenient method. The products were characterized by TEM, XRD, and UV-vis spectra. To make the catalysts achieve the highest photocatalytic activity under UV light illumination, the Ag content of Ag@TiO2 was optimized. The results showed that Ag@TiO2-doped Fe3+ extend their absorption into the visible region. Among the Fe3+-doped samples, Ag@Fe-TiO2 with low Ag content showed higher photocatalytic activity under visible light illumination. An excessive added amount of Ag would reduce Fe3+ to Fe2+ and make them difficult to be incorporated into the lattice of titania. From the experiments, we found that Fe3+ ions could stabilize the Ag@TiO2 colloid by holding back the aggregation of the core-shell nanoparticles.

PZyf5uqZ.title: XAFS studies on the local structures of Ti-HMS mesoporous molecular sieves and their photocatalytic properties.
PZyf5uqZ.abstract: Various Ti-containing HMS mesoporous molecular sieves having high surface areas and pore volumes have been prepared at ambient temperature. The Ti-HMS samples exhibited a well-defined XRD pattern of typical hexagonal lattice. UV-vis and XAFS spectral for the calcined forms of Ti-HMS indicated that the Ti ions are tetrahedrally coordinated in the framework of HMS for the samples of Ti-HMS(1) and Ti-HMS(2), while at least a fraction of Ti-oxides in Ti-HMS(10) is in octahedral coordination. UV irradiation of the Ti-HMS catalysts in the presence of NO was found to lead to the decomposition of NO to form N2, O2, and N2O at 273 K with different yields and product distributions. The photocatalytic performance of Ti-oxides appears to be completely modified by their incorporation structure and reaction environment. High efficiency and selectivity for the formation of N2 and O2 in the photocatalytic decomposition of NO was achieved with the Ti-HMS(1) having highly dispersed isolated tetrahedral titanium oxide species, while the reactivity decreased with an increase in the Ti content.

LRej1Pyu.title: Investigations on the effect of Mn ions on the local structure and photocatalytic activity of Cu(I)-ZSM-5 catalysts.
LRej1Pyu.abstract: The introduction of Mn ions into Cu(I)-ZSM-5 was found to lead to an enhancement of the photocatalytic activity for the direct decomposition of N2O into N2 and O2 at 298 K. Various in-situ techniques such as ESR, photoluminescence, XAFS as well as a combination of CO-FT-IR and CO-TPD measurements revealed that the accommodation of Mn ions within ZSM-5 zeolite cavities significantly affects the location sites of the ion-exchanged Cu(II) ions as well as the local structure of the Cu(I) ion species formed by evacuation at high temperatures. Moreover, the introduction of Mn ions into ZSM-5 led to an increase in the amount of 3-coordinated Cu(I) species at the main channel of the zeolite, playing a major role as the active species for the photocatalytic decomposition of N2O into N2 and O2.

80TAQXDc.title: Hydrothermal doping method for preparation of Cr3+-TiO 2 photocatalysts with concentration gradient distribution of Cr 3+
80TAQXDc.abstract: Cr3+-doped anatase titanium dioxide photocatalysts were prepared by the combination of sol-gel process with hydrothermal treatment. The samples were characterized by UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction (XRD), Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area (SBET), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), atomic absorption flame emission spectroscopy (AAS), electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). It was confirmed that Cr substitutes Ti 4+ in TiO2 lattice in trivalent ionic state, and the concentrations of dopants Cr3+ decrease from the exterior to the interior of doped TiO2. The photocatalytic activity of Cr-TiO 2 was investigated for the photocatalytic degradation of XRG aqueous solution both under UV and visible light irradiation. Due to the excitation of 3d electron of Cr3+ to the conduction band of TiO2, Cr-TiO2 shows a good ability for absorbing the visible light to degrade XRG. Doping of chromium ions effectively improves the photocatalytic activity under both UV light irradiation and visible light irradiation with an optimal doping concentration of 0.15% and 0.2%, respectively. The special distribution of dopants Cr3+ seems having a good effect on enhancing the photocatalytic activity of Cr-TiO2. © 2005 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

i2BqnrLt.title: Synthesis of Fe3+ doped ordered mesoporous TiO2 with enhanced visible light photocatalytic activity and highly crystallized anatase wall
i2BqnrLt.abstract: Fe3+ doped mesoporous TiO2 with ordered mesoporous structure were successfully prepared by the solvent evaporation-induced self-assembly process using P123 as soft template. The properties and structure of Fe3+ doped mesoporous TiO2 were characterized by means of XRD, EPR, BET, TEM, and UV-vis absorption spectra. The characteristic results clearly show that the amount of Fe3+ dopant affects the mesoporous structure as well as the visible light absorption of the catalysts. The photocatalytic activity of the prepared mesoporous TiO2 was evaluated from an analysis of the photodegradation of methyl orange under visible light irradiation. The results indicate that the sample of 0.50%Fe-MTiO2 exhibits the highest visible light photocatalytic activity compared with other catalysts. © Springer Science+Business Media B.V. 2010.

uOsDIkAi.title: Study on visible light photocatalytic activity and mechanism of spherical Bi12TiO20 nanoparticles prepared by low-power hydrothermal method
uOsDIkAi.abstract: Graphical abstract Research highlights ▶ Synthesiaing Bi 12 TiO 20 nanoparticles within 2 h hydrothermal treatment. ▶ Bi 12 TiO 20 has spherical structures with good dispersion and high BET surface area. ▶ Bi 12 TiO 20 has a high activity under visible light irradiation. ▶ The photocatalytic mechanisms were identified. Abstract Bismuth titanate (Bi 12 TiO 20 ) nanoparticles with spherical structures and good dispersion were synthesized hydrothermally using C 6 H 13 BiN 2 O 7 ·H 2 O and TiCl 3 in the presence of polyethylene glycol (PEG). Only 2 h of hydrothermal process was needed which means the whole process of preparation was a less power consumption. X-ray diffraction (XRD) proved that the samples were in pure cubic phase. UV–vis diffuse reflection spectra showed the band gap of Bi 12 TiO 20 is about 2.65 eV. Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) analysis showed that the Bi 12 TiO 20 samples have higher surface areas. Visible-light-induced photodegradation of acid orange 7 (AO7) on Bi 12 TiO 20 was investigated. It was found that Bi 12 TiO 20 -assisted photocatalytic degradation of AO7 occurs via two processes: the photocatalytic process of Bi 12 TiO 20 semiconductor and the photosensitized process of AO7. Photocatalytic experiments in the presence of N 2 and the radical scavenger suggested that OH and O 2 − are two main active species in the whole degradation process. Keywords Bi 12 TiO 20 nanoparticles Ammonium Bismuth Citrate Acid orange 7 Photocatalytic degradation Active species 1 Introduction Environmental pollution and energy shortage are two of the most important problems which the mankind faces now. Since the discovery of the photocatalytic splitting of water on the TiO 2 electrodes by Fujishima and Honda [1] , the applications of semiconductor photocatalysts on solar energy conversion and degradation of pollutants have received great attention [2–5] . After about 40 years of research, the photocatalytic technology has been proved to be a promising method in solving energy and environmental problems. Among all the photocatalysts, TiO 2 attracts the most attention because of its chemical stability, nontoxicity, and high photocatalytic reactivity [6–8] , however, the band gap of the TiO 2 is 3.2 eV. It absorbs only the ultraviolet light ( λ < 400 nm), which only accounts for about 4% of the sunlight [9] . In order to improve the efficiency of the sunlight utilization, the development of visible-light-driven and stable oxide photocatalysts is highly desirable. To find a breakthrough, it is indispensable to control the valence band with orbitals of some elements instead of O2p. It has been found that bismuth is a potential candidate for such a valence band control element [10,11] . Recently, ternary bismuth oxide semiconductors, such as Bi 2 WO 6 [12,13] , BiVO 4 [14,15] , NaBiO 3 [16] and Bi 12 TiO 20 [17,18] have been widely studied as a class of promising photocatalysts which can respond under visible light. The Bi 12 TiO 20 crystals belong to a family of sillenite compounds with the general formula Bi 12 MO 20 where M represents a tetravalent ion or a combination of ions, which gives an average charge of 4+. The frame-work of Bi 12 TiO 20 is formed by Bi–O polyhedra, where Bi ions are coordinated with five oxygen ions that form an octahedral arrangement together with the stereochemically active 6s 2 lone electron pair of Bi 3+ [19] . The unique structure of Bi 12 TiO 20 is benefit for its application in the photocatalysis field. As a result, Bi 12 TiO 20 has received more and more attention as a photocatalytic material. Our group [20] has reported the hydrothermal preparation of Bi 12 TiO 20 in recent. In that system, Bi(NO 3 ) 3 ·5H 2 O was used as the Bi source while Ti(SO 4 ) 2 was used as the Ti source. Pure cubic Bi 12 TiO 20 (the products were named n-Bi 12 TiO 20 ) can be obtained when the reaction solution was hydrothermally treated at 180 °C for 24 h using PEG10000 as cosolvent. The as-prepared n-Bi 12 TiO 20 samples were nano-sized particles with 13.5 m 2 /g of BET surface area. The agglomeration phenomenon can be observed in those samples. Therefore, the original hydrothermal method is not suitable to synthesize the Bi 12 TiO 20 samples with good dispersion. Thus, the synthesis of visible-light-driven Bi 12 TiO 20 photocatalysts with controlled microstructure and improved photocatalytic efficiency is a subject of considerable research interest. In this work, we have successfully synthesized Bi 12 TiO 20 with good dispersion and uniform spherical morphology using Ammonium Bismuth Citrate (C 6 H 13 BiN 2 O 7 ·H 2 O) as Bi source material and TiCl 3 as the Ti source material. PEG in this hydrothermal system acts as cosolvent. In addition, using Bi 12 TiO 20 sample as photocatalyst, we have investigated in detail its catalytic efficient of acid orange 7 (AO7) degradation under visible light irradiation. We offer the first opportunity to research the possible photocatalytic mechanism of Bi 12 TiO 20 under visible light. 2 Experiment 2.1 Materials Titania P-25 (TiO 2 ; ca. 80% anatase, 20% rutile; BET area, ca. 50 m 2 /g) was supplied by Degussa Co. Ammonium Bismuth Citrate (C 6 H 13 BiN 2 O 7 ·H 2 O) was purchased from Aladdin Co. while AO7 was obtained from Acros and used without further purification. Other major reagents were of analytical purity and supplied by China National Medicines Corporation. Double distilled water was used throughout this study. 2.2 Preparation of Bi 12 TiO 20 photocatalysts All samples were prepared by a standard procedure. Typically, 2.5 mmol of C 6 H 13 BiN 2 O 7 ·H 2 O were dissolved in 10 mL 20% (volume ratio) HNO 3 . 0.208 mM (Bi:Ti = 12:1) of different Ti source material (such as Ti(SO 4 ) 2 , TiCl 3 , TiCl 4 , Ti(OC 4 H 9 ) 4 ) were dissolved in 5 mL of double distilled water. Aqueous solutions of Bi source material and Ti source material were mixed together and then vigorous stirred for 1 h. The 0.9 g PEG10000 were dissolved into 10 mL of double distilled water and added dropwise into the reaction solution. One mole of NaOH aqueous solution was also added slowly to adjust the pH. Afterward, this suspension was stirred for 30 min and then transferred into a 100 mL stainless steel autoclave up to about 80% of its capacity. The autoclave was kept at 180 °C for different time and cooled to room temperature after the reaction time. The precipitates were washed with deionized water and ethanol for several times and then dried at 100 °C for 2 h to obtain the final products. 2.3 Characterization of Bi 12 TiO 20 photocatalysts The powder X-ray diffraction analysis of the prepared catalyst was carried out at room temperature with a Rigaku D/max 2550 VB/PC apparatus using Cu Kα radiation ( λ = 1.5406 Å) and a graphite monochromator, operated at 40 kV and 30 mA. The BET of the sample was determined through nitrogen adsorption at 77 K (Micromeritics ASAP 2010). The sample was degassed at 473 K before the measurement. The UV–vis absorbance spectra were recorded for the dry-pressed disk sample using a Scan UV–vis spectrophotometer (Varian, Cary 500) equipped with an integrating sphere assembly. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis of the samples was done using a JSM-2100F (JEOL) instrument and the electron beam accelerating voltage was 200 kV. 2.4 Photocatalytic activities test The photocatalytic degradation of AO7 with visible light was used to evaluate the photocatalytic activities of the samples. A 1000 W halogen lamp was used as the light source with a 420 nm cutoff filter to provide visible light irradiation. During the reaction, a water-cooling system cooled the water-jacketed photochemical reactor to maintain the solution at 25 °C. In each experiment, 0.08 g of photocatalyst was added to 80 mL of AO7 solution (20 mg/L). Before illumination, the suspensions were magnetically stirred in the dark for 30 min to ensure the adsorption–desorption equilibrium between the photocatalyst and AO7. Then the solution was exposed to visible light irradiation under magnetic stirring. At given time intervals, 4 mL of suspension was sampled and centrifuged to remove the photocatalyst particles. Then, the catalyst-free dye solution were analyzed by a Cary 100 UV–vis spectrometer to record intensity of the maximum band at 484 nm in the UV–vis absorption spectra. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Bi 12 TiO 20 nanoparticles The phase and composition of the products were investigated by XRD measurements. Different Ti sources are used in this work in order to determine the application scope of this hydrothermal system. Fig. 1 A shows the XRD spectra of the samples prepared using four kinds of Ti sources: TiCl 4 , Ti(OC 4 H 9 ) 4 , Ti(SO 4 ) 2 and TiCl 3 . Compared with the JCPDS Card No. 34-0097, the Standard Card of cubic Bi 12 TiO 20 , all diffraction peaks of four curves can be indexed to cubic Bi 12 TiO 20 . In other words, four different kinds of Ti sources can be used to prepare cubic Bi 12 TiO 20 when the reaction solution is hydrothermally treated for 8 h at 180 °C. The hydrothermal system using C 6 H 13 BiN 2 O 7 ·H 2 O as Bi source is universal to different Ti sources which is benefit for the promotion of the hydrothermal method. Fig. 1 B shows the XRD spectra of samples prepared using different Ti sources with 2 h of hydrothermal treatment at 180 °C. As seen in curves b, c and d, peaks observed at 32.0° and 46.8° do not belong to the peaks of cubic Bi 12 TiO 20 . So using TiCl 4 , Ti(OC 4 H 9 ) 4 or Ti(SO 4 ) 2 as Ti sources, 2 h of hydrothermal time is not enough for the formation of pure cubic Bi 12 TiO 20 . When TiCl 3 was used as Ti source, pure Bi 12 TiO 20 can be obtained at 180 °C after 2 h of hydrothermal treatment. All Ti sources are first dissolved in double distilled water without other solvents. However, the Ti(SO 4 ) 2 is slightly soluble in water while TiCl 4 and Ti(OC 4 H 9 ) 4 will precipitate in double distilled water. These two phenomena are not conducive to the following reaction. TiCl 3 can be evenly mixed with double distilled water producing lots of Ti 3+ to react with Bi 3+ . The using TiCl 3 as Ti source can shorten the hydrothermal time which means it is the best choice among four Ti sources. To reveal the effect of hydrothermal treatment time on the Bi 12 TiO 20 , time-dependent experiments were carefully conducted. TiCl 3 was used as Ti source. Fig. 1 C shows the XRD spectra of samples synthesized with different hydrothermal time. In the preparation of pure sillenite Bi 12 TiO 20 , main peaks of cubic Bi 12 TiO 20 have been found when hydrothermal time was only 1 h. But a metastable phase (bump at about 28.0°) also appeared which means 1 h hydrothermal time is not enough for the formation of pure cubic Bi 12 TiO 20 . Pure cubic Bi 12 TiO 20 was finally obtained with 2 h of hydrothermal treatment. After the hydrothermal treatment was proceeded to 8 h, the peak intensity got stronger which showed the crystallinity of the sample was developing with the prolongation of hydrothermal time. FT-IR spectra of prepared samples are showed in Fig. 2 . As reported by previous papers [21,22] , the cubic Bi 12 TiO 20 has four peaks at 457, 535, 586 and 663 cm −1 , corresponding to the characteristic peaks of sillenite having Bi–O vibration modes. As shown in Fig. 2 A, all of the four characteristic peaks can been observed in the samples with 8 h of hydrothermal treatment at 180 °C using different Ti sources. But when the hydrothermal time is just 2 h ( Fig. 2 B), the four peaks are not very obvious in the sample using TiCl 4 as Ti source. This result is in good agreement with the XRD results discussed above. The UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra of the as-synthesized Bi 12 TiO 20 (PEG10000, hydrothermal temperature: 180 °C; hydrothermal time: 2 h; pH = 12.5) is shown in Fig. 3 . As a comparison, the spectra of P-25 titania were also measured. The absorption edge of the Bi 12 TiO 20 sample extended nearly to the whole spectra of visible light, which implies the possibility of high photocatalytic activity of this material under visible light. In compared with P-25, the absorption onset wavelength of Bi 12 TiO 20 was shifted 100 nm to visible region. The color of synthesized Bi 12 TiO 20 was deep green, which was in accordance with its absorption spectrum. It is well-known that for a crystalline semiconductor [23] , the optical absorption near the band edge follows the formula: (1) α h ν = A ( h ν − Eg ) n / 2 where α , h , ν , Eg, and A are the absorption coefficient, Planck's constant, the light frequency, the band gap, and a constant, respectively. Among these, n describes the characteristics of the transition in a semiconductor. For Bi 12 TiO 20 , the value of n is 1. The plot of ( αhν ) 2 vs. hν based on the direct transition is shown in the inset of Fig. 3 . Therefore, the energy of the band gap could be estimated to be about 2.65 eV for Bi 12 TiO 20 in our case. This indicates that the nanosized Bi 12 TiO 20 has a suitable band gap for photocatalytic decomposition of organic contaminants under visible light irradiation. The morphology and microstructure of Bi 12 TiO 20 samples prepared under the best hydrothermal condition (Ti: TiCl 3 ; T : 180 °C; t : 2 h) were revealed by TEM images ( Fig. 4 A–C ). The panoramic views shown in Fig. 4 A and B indicate that the as-prepared products are composed of sphere structures. The good dispersion of these samples shows the using C 6 H 13 BiN 2 O 7 ·H 2 O as Bi source can control the agglomeration at a large extent. As shown in Fig. 4 C which is the HRTEM image of Bi 12 TiO 20 sample, the Bi 12 TiO 20 samples were spherical in shape and less than 10 nm in size. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas of Bi 12 TiO 20 prepared under different condition were shown in Table 1 . When the hydrothermal time was kept in 8 h, the sample prepared using TiCl 3 as Ti source had the larger BET surface area in compared with samples synthesizing using three other Ti sources. The largest BET surface area of the sample can reach to 21.95 m 2 /g, higher than n-Bi 12 TiO 20 (13.50 m 2 /g) [20] . The combination of C 6 H 13 BiN 2 O 7 ·H 2 O and TiCl 3 can increase the BET surface area in compared with the Bi(NO 3 ) 3 ·5H 2 O and Ti(SO 4 ) 2 . 3.2 The role of Ammonium Bismuth Citrate In previous research, Bi(NO 3 ) 3 is typically used as the Bi source in the preparation of Bi 12 TiO 20 [20] . As shown in formula (2) , Bi(NO 3 ) 3 can be fully ionized in acidic solution and produce great amount of Bi 3+ . When NaOH aqueous solution was added in the reaction solution, lots of Bi 3+ can react with Ti 4+ and produce white precipitate immediately. This kind of quick reaction is the reason why agglomeration phenomenon is serious when using Bi(NO 3 ) 3 as Bi source. When C 6 H 13 BiN 2 O 7 instead of Bi(NO 3 ) 3 is selected as the Bi source in this new system, the reaction solution kept transparent under stirring even after adding the NaOH aqueous solution. C 6 H 13 BiN 2 O 7 is one of the metal chelates which can produce the complex of Bi 3+ with citric anions, as shown in formula (3) [9] . Because of the coordination, Bi 3+ will not directly react with Ti 4+ and the precipitate will not appear when the reaction is in normal temperature. As the temperature increased during the hydrothermal process, the complex will gradually decompose and release Bi 3+ slowly, followed by the reaction with Ti 4+ . Thus, the nucleation and growth process of Bi 12 TiO 20 occur slowly during the hydrothermal process, which might be similar to that in homogeneous precipitation. In this precipitation process, the microstructure of the product is dominantly controlled by the nucleation and anisotropic growth of the Bi 12 TiO 20 ; thus small particles will be obtained using C 6 H 13 BiN 2 O 7 as Bi source. In addition, this kind of reaction in a homogeneous solution is benefit for shortening the hydrothermal time and achieving the low-power preparation of Bi 12 TiO 20 . As shown in our previous research [20] , PEG10000 works as a template. Lots of spherical particles were obtained using long-chain PEG, which is due to the fact that a long-length PEG can confine more than one direction of the growing colloid and finally form spherical colloids [24] . As a result, Bi 12 TiO 20 nanoparticles with spherical morphology and higher surface area are obtained. (2) Bi ( N O 3 ) 3 ⟶ H + B i 3 + + 3 N O 3 − (3) Bi ( N H 3 ) 2 C 6 H 7 O 7 ↔ B i 3 + + ( N H 3 ) 2 C 6 H 7 O 7 3 − 3.3 Degradation of AO7 The photodegradation of AO7 were carried out under visible light illumination at wavelengths longer than 420 nm in order to test the photocatalytic performance of the Bi 12 TiO 20 samples prepared using C 6 H 13 BiN 2 O 7 as Bi source. For comparison, the photodegradation of AO7 by P-25 was also carried out. The results displayed in Fig. 5 show that AO7 solution was stable under visible light irradiation in the absence of any photocatalyst. Keeping the AO7 solution in neutral condition, when using Bi 12 TiO 20 as the photocatalyst, total degradation rate of AO7 was over 75% within 6 h irradiation, much higher than the P-25 which only reached 25% of the total decomposition. The solution pH has great influence on the surface charge of the semiconductor photocatalyst, which will also affect the degradation result. The photodegradation of AO7 over Bi 12 TiO 20 with different initial pHs is showed in Fig. 6 A . The photodegradation rate of the AO7 dye increased when the pH of solution changed from 6.0 to 4.0. It is well known that AO7 is a kind of anionic dyes. The acidic environment is helpful to increase adsorption of AO7 on the Bi 12 TiO 20 surface [25] and thus, indirectly, the photocatalytic decomposition rate of AO7. As a result, total degradation rate of AO7 was over 90% within 6 h irradiation when the pH of solution was kept at 4.0. In previous study, it has been proved the BET surface area of Bi 12 TiO 20 is an important factor in the degradation of AO7 [20] . On the one hand, the higher surface area can increase the amount of adsorption of AO7. On the other hand, higher BET surface area provides more active sites for photocatalytic reaction [26] . As shown in Table 1 , the hydrothermal time can influence the BET surface at a large degree. Therefore, the photocatalytic results of Bi 12 TiO 20 prepared under different hydrothermal time are shown in Fig. 6 B. The sample with the largest BET surface area (21.95 m 2 /g) has the best photocatalytic activity. In conclusion, the shorting hydrothermal time increases the BET surface area of Bi 12 TiO 20 , and then improves the photocatalytic result of sample. The repeatability of visible photocatalytic activity for the Bi 12 TiO 20 samples prepared using C 6 H 13 BiN 2 O 7 as Bi source was investigated. It is apparent that the degradation curves are very close to each other within five times, implying the excellent stability of photocatalytic activity for the Bi 12 TiO 20 samples. Thus, the Bi 12 TiO 20 samples can be reused many times without diminution in photocatalytic activity, which extends the practical application of TiO 2 . 3.4 Photocatalytic mechanism of AO7 by Bi 12 TiO 20 nanoparticles Professor Zhu and coworkers [11] have proposed that photocatalytic process and photosensitized process effected together in the degradation of RhB by Bi 2 WO 6 . In our experiment, the photocatalytic process of Bi 12 TiO 20 semiconductor is confirmed by degradation of 2,4-dichlorophenol (2,4-DCP). Fig. 7 shows the photocatalytic results of 2,4-DCP by the Bi 12 TiO 20 prepared under the best hydrothermal conditions (Ti: TiCl 3 , T = 180 °C, t = 2 h). The adsorption capacity (only 2.5%) on Bi 12 TiO 20 of 2,4-DCP is limited. After 6 h visible light irradiation, the total degradation rate reached 25%. 2,4-DCP dissolved in water will form a colorless solution and this solution is very stable under light irradiation. Because photosensitized process cannot occur in a colorless solution under visible light irradiation, the degradation of 2,4-DCP can only be attributed to the photocatalytic activity of Bi 12 TiO 20 . This experimental result proves that the Bi 12 TiO 20 nanoparticles have the photocatalytic ability under visible light in the degrading process of AO7. Consequently, the photocatalysis process also exists in the decoloration of AO7. A large amount of adsorption of AO7 might influence the research on the photocatalytic mechanism of Bi 12 TiO 20 , so the AO7 solution of pH = 6.0 was adopted in the following photocatalytic experiments. In order to determine the main active species responsible for the degradation of AO7, comparison experiments in N 2 atmosphere and scavenger-loaded condition were undertaken. The AO7 solution with Bi 12 TiO 20 photocatalyst was sealed and purged with N 2 for 1 h before irradiation to drive out a part of dissolved oxygen and kept purging on until the reaction was completed. As seen in Fig. 8 , the result is that the degradation rate in the air equilibrium condition is 76%, much higher than in the N 2 equilibrium condition which is only about 7%. The 7% of degradation rate might be attributed to the absorption of AO7 on the Bi 12 TiO 20 nanoparticles before the visible light irradiation. The result that AO7 cannot be degraded on Bi 12 TiO 20 under N 2 -purged condition indicates oxygen is the main source of the active species. As shown in formula (4), (5) and (6) , O 2 − , HO 2 and OH are three possible oxidative intermediate species formed from the O 2 [27,28] . According to formula (7) , HO 2 is unstable and automatically generate O 2 and H 2 O 2 . So the role of HO 2 will not discussed in this research. The degradation results of AO7 in the presence of methanol (CH 3 OH, a quencher of OH in the solution [29] ) and KI (a quench of positive holes (h + ) and OH radical on catalyst surface [30,31] ) are shown in Fig. 9 . Adding 50 mM of CH 3 OH in the AO7 solution, the degradation rate decreased from 76% to 50%, showing the OH in the solution can affect the degradation result of AO7. When 2 mM of KI was added into the AO7 solution, the degradation rate decreased from 76% to 30%. Because of the bad result in degrading AO7 in the N 2 equilibrium condition, the positive (h + ) holes is not the main active species. So the OH radical on catalyst surface is the main oxidative species responsible for the degradation of the AO7 dye solution. In conclusion, OH radical is the most important active species in the photocatalytic process of AO7 by Bi 12 TiO 20 nanoparticles. (4) O 2 + e − → O 2 − (5) O 2 − + H + → HO 2 (6) O 2 − + e − + 2 H + → H 2 O 2 ⟶ e − OH + O H − (7) 2HO 2 → O 2 + H 2 O 2 The possible degradation mechanism of AO7 over Bi 12 TiO 20 under visible light irradiation is drawn in Scheme 1 . The whole degradation process consists of two parts: the photocatalytic activity of Bi 12 TiO 20 nanoparticles and the photosensitized process of AO7. As seen in following formulas, four main reactions are involved in the photocatalytic process: (1) Bi 12 TiO 20 nanoparticles produced h + and e − under light irradiation (as seen in formula (8) ); (2) O 2 reacted with e − and formed the superoxide (O 2 − ) and h + reacted with –OH group absorbed on surface of Bi 12 TiO 20 nanoparticles (as seen in formula (4) and (9) ); (3) further reaction of O 2 − produced OH (as seen in formula (6) ); (4) OH and O 2 − worked together to degrade AO7 into small molecules (as seen in formula (10) ). (8) B i 12 TiO 20 + h ν → h + + e − O 2 + e − → O 2 − O 2 − + e − + 2 H + → H 2 O 2 ⟶ e − OH + O H − (9) h + + OH − → OH (10) O 2 − / OH + AO 7 → degraded products In the photosensitized process, the AO7 dye first absorbed the incident photo flux. Then, the photogenerated electrons were transferred to the excited state of the dye. The photoelectrons of the excited state were immediately injected into the CB of Bi 12 TiO 20 . The photoelectrons in the CB were then captured by O 2 and formed the O 2 − which can lead to the mineralization of the dyes (as seen in formula (11)–(14) ). (11) AO 7 + h ν → AO 7 * (12) B i 12 TiO 20 + AO 7 * → AO 7 + + B i 12 TiO 20 ( e − ) (13) B i 12 TiO 20 ( e − ) + O 2 → B i 12 TiO 20 + O 2 − (14) O 2 − + AO 7 + → degraded products Both the photocatalytic process and the photosensitized process would work concurrently when the light wavelength was longer than 420 nm. OH and O 2 − are two main active species in the whole process. 4 Conclusions Bi 12 TiO 20 nanoparticles were successfully synthesized under only 2 h hydrothermal treatment using C 6 H 13 BiN 2 O 7 as Bi source and TiCl 3 as Ti source. The as-prepared Bi 12 TiO 20 samples were composed of spherical structures with good dispersion and high BET surface area. The optical band gap of Bi 12 TiO 20 samples were estimated to be about 2.65 eV which showed Bi 12 TiO 20 can respond to the visible light. Visible-light-induced degradation of AO7 showed Bi 12 TiO 20 had a high activity for the AO7 degradation. The photocatalytic process of Bi 12 TiO 20 and the photosensitized process of AO7 were identified to exist in the degradation process of AO7 under visible light irradiation. The radical scavenger technologies suggest that OH and O 2 − took part in Bi 12 TiO 20 photocatalysis. Av1GEUn9.title: Photocatalytic reactivity of Ce-intercalated layered titanate prepared with a hybrid method based on ion-exchange and thermal treatment
Av1GEUn9.abstract: Ce-intercalated layered titanate (CeTO) was synthesized through an ion-exchange process combined with thermal treatment. According to X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis, the interlayer shrinkage, lattice cell contraction and lattice dislocation of CeTO occur during the ion-exchange process. The ion-exchange process lengthens the bond length of Ti–O in the a -axis direction, which results in a bathochromic shift of titanate in UV–vis spectrum. Calcination treatment intensifies the interlayer shrinkage and reduces the lattice dislocation via lattice rearrangement. The photocatalytic reactivity of CeTO is significantly improved with thermal treatment at 400 °C. EPR study shows that most of the intercalated cerium ions are oxidized to Ce 4+ after intercalation, while thermal treatment changes little the chemical valence of cerium ion. It is suggested that lattice dislocation but not chemical valence of cerium ion plays an important role in determining the photocatalytic activity of CeTO. Further, the photocatalytic reactivity of CeTO is much higher than cerium doped sodium titanate prepared by solid-state reaction (SSR) method.
